QUESTION.SPEAKER: Parer Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. I refer to the Prime Minister's recent statement in Seattle in relation to Mr Conrad Black's request for a further increase in the level of foreign ownership that:

QUESTION.PARA: . . . we will think about it but we want a commitment from you that the paper will be balanced.
After the election, did the government make good on this commitment and increase the foreign ownership level to 25 per cent?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Let me get a few things clear about this. In the first place, there is no application before the government to increase Mr Black's shareholding in John Fairfax Holdings Ltd. When the last increase was granted in April this year, the Treasurer said:

ANSWER.PARA: The Government will not countenance further increases in the permitted level of foreign involvement in mass circulation newspapers.
The Treasurer confirmed that in a press release last week, 19 November, and those words should be taken at their face value.

PARA.TAB: The Prime Minister met Mr Black in Canberra a few days ago. In his Lateline interview, Mr Black said in relation to that exchange that the Prime Minister:

ANSWER.PARA: . . . certainly did not give any undertaking to do anything and I made no specific suggestions.

The opposition has constantly tried—and again now through Senator Parer—to imply some kind of impropriety in discussions between Mr Black and Mr Keating before the federal election. We all know that Dr Hewson himself held at least one discussion with Mr Black before that election because, on the Business Sunday program yesterday, Mr Black said in relation to both that and his discussion with Mr Keating—

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I raise a point of order. This is an utterly predetermined and programmed answer. It is in no shape or form an answer to the question, which was: did the government make good on the commitment and increase the foreign ownership limit to 25 per cent? That is a very simple question. The minister has not in any shape or form purported to answer it, and you ought to bring him to order.
—Order! There is no point of order. The minister is dealing with the subject of the question that he was asked.

—I am dealing with the question in the way that I want to deal with it. I will get to the specific immediate point in issue in Senator Parer's question, but that can only be understood in the context of the whole series of events.
—You are looking tired.

—Of course I am tired; I just got off a plane two hours ago. In the context of this particular exchange, Mr Black said that he wrote about Dr Hewson's position that `this was not an issue with him and he was, in agreed phraseology, very relaxed about what our level of ownership would be in the event that he won the election'. So Dr Hewson's position, we are told, was to indicate very clearly to Mr Black that he would put no obstacles in the way and, in fact, would be `very relaxed' about an increase in the percentage after the election, regardless again of the balance or the fairness or the quality of the Fairfax newspapers.

PARA.TAB: Mr Black has stressed repeatedly that Mr Keating did not seek partisan pro-Labor treatment. Certainly Labor did not get any such treatment from the Fairfax press, as the editorials during the campaign amply confirmed. The point about the increase from 15 to 25 per cent was very simply this: it was to give Mr Black a stronger commercial basis on which to commit the finance and the technology that were necessary to rebuild Fairfax—something that was in everyone's interest.

It was not a question, when this was discussed between the two of them or when it was dealt with by the government, as it was in April this year after the election, of any political judgment being made, but an economic judgment—what was necessary to protect an investment that worked to everyone's advantage. That is the context, that is the background, they are the specifics, and that is the balance of this affair between the government's involvement through the Prime Minister and the opposition's involvement through Dr Hewson. Both of them had discussions with Mr Black about aspects of the issue. Dr Hewson's commitment to Mr Black, on the face of it—on the face of Mr Black's own account of those conversations—was a commitment that went much further than anything that Mr Keating or anyone in this government has been prepared to say to Mr Black at any time.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the minister for his answer. I ask again: did the Prime Minister make a private, secret pre-election commitment before the election? Did the government after the election increase the foreign ownership to 25 per cent?

—I have nothing to add to my answer. The increase was made after the election from 15 to 25 per cent for the reasons I have just indicated. There was a discussion with Mr Keating, as there was a discussion with Dr Hewson. It was not in the nature of a private, secret commitment, or anything along the lines that Senator Parer has suggested.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs. I refer to the conference of APEC leaders in Seattle which has just concluded. What outcomes were of particular significance to Australia? Does the government regard the APEC initiative as having been successful? What evaluation might reasonably be made at this time?

—It must be said that APEC, in both the ministerial meeting and the leaders' meeting which occurred over the weekend, was an absolutely outstanding success from any perspective, including—one would hope—that of the opposition in this country. There were at least seven major achievements from that meeting that I will enumerate quickly in explanation of that judgment.

PARA.TAB: Firstly, there was the mere holding of the meeting—the chemistry of its conduct which, on any view, on every account, was outstanding—and associated with that the decision to hold another meeting next year in Indonesia. Personal relationships and confidence building of this kind are a very necessary prelude to effective policy making. This simple aspect of the occasion, despite the cynicism which we are hearing already from those on the other side, simply cannot be overstated. In that respect, if nothing else, Mr Keating's judgment about initiating this would have been vindicated.

The second point is the terms of the vision statement itself and the commitment that entailed—that explicitly embraced—to a collective, self-conscious role by what was described as `the community of Asia Pacific economies'. In particular, the goal that was spelt out in that vision statement was a commitment to freer global and regional trade.

The third thing which was a crucial outcome and which contributed to its success was the very explicit statement by the leaders themselves, and even more explicit statements coming from the ministers on the Uruguay Round—the commitment to the successful conclusion of that round, combined with some very specific proposals about market access, which no doubt Senator Cook will want an opportunity to say something about at some later stage.

The fourth element was the commitment which emerged from all of the meetings to a very explicit and clear-cut trade facilitation agenda. A trade and investment framework document was agreed. A work program was agreed extending to the issues of standards, recognition of qualifications and harmonisation of procedures—especially in relation to customs—of addressing non-tariff barriers generally and addressing competition policy and its implications for anti-dumping. It was also agreed to work towards the establishment of a regional investment code.

It is absolutely crucial that it be understood, in a way that many commentators have not understood, that this is the heart and soul of the activity that APEC is now embarked upon—the specific nuts and bolts trade facilitation measures that will have enormous implications for reducing costs and barriers to access in this particular region. It is crucial that it also be realised that this meeting represents a very big step forward from what has been the preoccupation, up until now, with simply information gathering, transparency information exchange and policy dialogue to specific action programs that will produce agreed results of that kind.

Fifthly, there is the technical cooperation agenda, especially in the areas of energy, telecommunications, transport, human resource development and addressing the infrastructure bottlenecks that have been so well described by Mr Keating and others in their contributions to that meeting.

A sixth outcome of the meeting—if this still is not good enough for Senator Hill—was that several new dimensions to the APEC dialogue were established and put on the record: new meetings of finance and economic ministers to discuss macro-economic developments and responses to them; new attention being paid to the establishment of a trade and environment dialogue; and a new kind of involvement of business through business round tables.

Seventhly, and finally, there was a resolution of some very difficult and sensitive questions about the membership of the organisation with a very clear-cut agreement being reached on the need to consolidate it at its present manageable levels. I think Australia can be very pleased and proud of this particular meeting and the contribution we have made to the initiation of APEC in 1989 and its development since, particularly on this occasion.

TALK.START.PARA: —Could the Leader of the Government in the Senate explain why the Treasurer's press release of 20 April 1993 implied that the decision to raise the foreign ownership limit was made to accommodate `the valid need of foreign investors to safeguard their financial and managerial commitment to their newspapers', when we now know from the Prime Minister's `shameless in Seattle' comments that before the election he wanted a commitment that coverage of the Sydney Morning Herald would be balanced and that after the election `I on behalf of the government made good a commitment to reconsider them and took them to 25 per cent'? Why did the Treasurer's press release disguise the real reasons for this decision when it was announced?

—The Treasurer's press release articulated exactly the reason that the government had regard to in increasing the stake from 15 to 25 per cent. That is exactly the reason I spoke about a few moments ago when I said that the kind of financial and technological commitment that was being sought by everyone of Conrad Black, in relation to the Fairfax group, was one that could realistically and commercially be guaranteed and ensured only by a consolidation of the shareholding in question at a higher level. That was the central reason and certainly it is the reason that I recall being absolutely central in the discussions that took place when this matter was considered by the government after the election.

PARA.TAB: Of course it is the case that governments will always have regard, just as oppositions will always have regard, to the quality of the news media. The Prime Minister made the point in Seattle on the weekend that no government is going to give such agreement to a proprietor who behaves, as he said, in a partisan way or immaturely. That cuts both ways.

We are not talking about giving special deals to people who give special support to their own side. We are talking about having an attitude, as a responsible government, which is in favour of a responsible media. Of course it is the case that we were not seeking at any stage, nor do we now, nor is it the Prime Minister's view that he wants, any kind of craven obsequiousness so far as the press of this country is concerned. That is highly unlikely ever to be achieved. It certainly was not achieved in the last election where, as I remember, every Fairfax paper came out against the government. Nonetheless, we made the decision that we did on 20 April to increase the stake because of the economic reasons and commercial reasons that I have mentioned which constitute a very clear-cut, very self-contained and very self-evident rationale for that particular increase.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Does the minister seriously deny that Mr Keating's remarks in Seattle make it blatantly obvious that any increase was conditional upon balanced coverage and had nothing whatsoever to do with the national interest? Is this not simply political corruption of the worst sort?

—It is political grandstanding of the most squalid and pathetic kind that we are hearing from Senator Alston, Senator Parer and everyone else on the opposition side who tries to make something of this. The Prime Minister's statement in Seattle was as I have described it, but it was in the context that I have described. The government's decision was made for exactly the reasons that Mr Dawkins set out on 20 April and which I have stated again here today.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Science and Small Business. I refer the minister to the statement released this morning by the South Australian Arnold government on business and economic development, particularly in relation to the proposal to develop Woomera as a satellite launch and recovery site. Is the minister able to provide the Senate with details about the partnership between the federal and state Labor governments on specific proposals which can lead to the further development of Australia's space industry?

—I thank Senator McKiernan for his question about the important developments taking place in the development of an Australian space program in conjunction with the South Australian government. It is the aim of both governments to have a viable space program operating in Australia by the year 2000.

PARA.TAB: With the existing infrastructure that is available at Woomera from the space program that operated in Australia in the 1960s and 1970s, Australia is well placed to launch light earth orbiting satellites, LEOs, particularly those satellites in low polar orbit, because of our geographic, climatic and political advantages. With the development of Woomera we will be able to provide interested countries and space programs with the ability to launch satellites from Woomera on a commercial basis—I emphasise `commercial basis'.

It has been estimated by some commercial consortiums that the existing infrastructure at Woomera, left over from the space program in the 1960s and 1970s, at today's value is probably worth around $100 million. I have asked my department and the Australian Space Office to investigate what it would cost to bring these facilities up to standard to launch light earth orbiting satellites on a commercial basis.

Irrespective of that study, there has been interest from overseas in using Woomera, particularly from Germany. Next year Germany will want to recover one of its scientific satellites in its express program at Woomera. I hope by February next year that Australia and Germany will have signed a treaty to enable the recovery of that satellite. Discussions are now continuing with the Germans to see whether it is possible for future express satellites to be launched from Woomera.

There are also opportunities emerging from Russian interests which, with their capabilities, may be interested in launching LEO satellites from Australia. As a result of my visit to Japan three weeks ago, I arranged for a delegation from the Japanese space agency, NASDA, to visit Australia early next year to look at ways in which cooperation between both countries can take place to develop a space program.

These opportunities, collaboratively developed between the federal government and the state government of South Australia, are opportunities for the future. I remind the Senate that it was also a Senate transport and infrastructure committee report some two years ago that raised these issues. It is good to see that some honourable senators opposite acknowledge that. There are opportunities for us. I congratulate the South Australian government for taking up these initiatives with the federal government to develop a space program during the 1990s.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. I want to go back a step in this Conrad Black-Keating issue—back to the decision making process. I refer to the original application by the Conrad Black-led Tourang consortium for the takeover of the Fairfax group and ask: was the original bid rejected by the Foreign Investment Review Board on a 2:2 decision? What criteria did Treasurer Dawkins use to override Treasurer Kerin's decision to accept the Foreign Investment Review Board recommendation? Will the government publish both reports, as recommended by the Lee committee inquiry into the print media?
—This goes back somewhat further than my experience with this matter. It goes back, as I recall, to at least 1991.
—You weren't a minister but you were a parliamentary secretary.

—I was parliamentary secretary; I was not, unfortunately, a member of the cabinet. I would love to have been but I was not, so I was not present for the discussions of these matters. The most important facts to remember with regard to this matter are two; firstly, that the Foreign Investment Review Board is fundamentally an advisory body—
—That's right.

—That is what the legislation says. I do not know why Senator Kernot thinks that is a stunning revelation. If she was in some doubt before, I advise her that it is an advisory body and decisions are made by ministers, as they should be in a representative democracy. The nature of its advice is not disclosed because it is advice in the normal decision making process for ministers. General policy positions are disclosed but the handling of individual companies' applications has always been treated as commercial-in-confidence and that commercial-in-confidence principle has also been applied in the normal course.

PARA.TAB: So the advisory role and the commercial-in-confidence principles would seem to me to indicate that there are some significant limitations on the capacity to comply with those matters the honourable senator raises, but I will refer any outstanding issues to the Treasurer to see whether he has anything to add.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the minister for his answer and ask him on the point of principle: what is this government afraid of in opening up the decision making processes of the Foreign Investment Review Board to parliamentary and public scrutiny? It is not just a matter of commercial-in-confidence information. There are a whole lot of reasons that can be given for why, for example, the Australian Independent Newspaper consortium bid was rejected. Is it not true that the Foreign Investment Review Board really exists to do the Treasurer's or the Prime Minister's bidding after the event when private arrangements have been entered into by the Prime Minister of this country?

—There is a very interesting implication in that question, that somehow the FIRB rejected the AIN bid. The AIN bid was an Australian bid. It was not subject even to consideration by the FIRB because it was not—
—Kerin wrote to AIN.

—Yes, but it was not subject to its consideration because it was not a foreign investment proposal. So it is quite clear that the circumstances could not arise as it relates to AIN by definition. But the situation as to whether the FIRB processes should be more open and transparent is not a matter about which—notwithstanding the enthusiasm over there—I ever recall the opposition saying that it was going to make FIRB applications by individual companies more public, and nor should it. In all the time that I have been aware of it we have dealt with them consistently, as we intend to do. I do not think there is anything added by the supplementary question, but if there is I will refer that to the Treasurer as well.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Trade. Now that the APEC ministerial meeting and the APEC leaders' meeting have concluded, is the minister able to inform the Senate how they have furthered Australia's interests in regional trade and investment? Specifically, what has been done that will facilitate trade in the region? How will the Australian business community be able to influence events? Most importantly, what does all this mean for the Uruguay Round?

—The heart and soul of APEC is trade, investment and regional economic growth. We did a lot of things in Seattle which have advanced the cause for Australia in all of those areas. I should count the ways in which we did those things. I subscribe to and support the answer that Senator Gareth Evans gave earlier in question time to a question about the Seattle conference. The leaders and the ministers did advance our regional interests quite considerably.

PARA.TAB: The first and fundamental thing that should be said is that APEC commits itself absolutely to the idea of multilateral trade negotiations. That is the overarching principle that we recognise. In Seattle we brought down a major statement which has advanced, in my view, the progress towards the successful conclusion of the Uruguay Round this year.

We did not content ourselves with fine rhetoric and nice words; we actually did practical things. We tabled a market access proposal which most of the countries which are contracting parties to the GATT in APEC put their names to and which has advanced market access debate in the Uruguay Round much further than what it was when the G7 last met in Tokyo back in July. We have done that.

The significant beauty of all of that for Australia is that, since we have been on a course of reducing tariffs ourselves, there is no area in that enhanced market access package in which we need to modify any of our tariff policies at all. We are within that according to our existing tariff policy.

Regionally, we also did a substantial body of work on trade and investment. Senator Gareth Evans mentioned the trade and investment framework for the area. That does three things. First, it sets out our views in terms of the principles for trade and investment within the whole of the Asia-Pacific region. This has not been done before. We have now done it. It is a significant advance in getting a coherent viewpoint from all of the dynamic economies of this region.

Secondly, it establishes a committee on trade and investment. Australia has chaired the ad hoc committee that led up to the development of this committee. The Republic of Korea is now in the chair. We now have a way in which we can facilitate our progress by leadership through that committee on developing a substantial work program, which is the third thing that the framework does.

The work program sets out a solid agenda on both policy development and trade facilitation issues. On policy we have agreed that trade ministers will meet after the conclusion of the Uruguay Round to consider the outcome of that round and look at what we should do next for this region of the world. On facilitation we have committed ourselves to the harmonisation of customs administration and practice, particularly in the areas of paperless trade. We are going to look at how we can deal with non-tariff barriers to trade and investment and further impediments in that area. We have agreed on a process in which we can come to mutual recognition of product standards and professional qualifications in the area. We are establishing a regional electronic data exchange for tariff levels throughout the region.

One part of this question was: how can business participate. All of us believe that business has a major role in the development of APEC. Philip Brass, from Pacific Dunlop, was there as a voice of Australian business. He participated in the business forum that ran alongside the meeting of governments. There will be, I understand from the leaders, a forum in which business leaders—two from each country—can now participate in the future to make sure that APEC maintains that business focus.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate in his capacity as Minister representing the Prime Minister. Why should the people of Australia believe the Treasurer's statement last Friday that there will not be any change to the government's policy in relation to foreign ownership, given that he said precisely the same thing in February 1992 and having regard to the fact that the Prime Minister made it clear that Mr Black's latest request for an increase was still under active consideration, saying, `something easily given isn't generally something worth having'? In light of the Prime Minister's obvious willingness to do a further deal on this issue, will the minister now give a categorical and unequivocal assurance that there will be absolutely no increase in the level of foreign ownership during the life of any government led by Mr Keating?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I gave a response earlier on to that very question when I said that the Treasurer had, in his statement last Friday, 19 November, repeated the basic terms of his statement of 20 April, which was the result of a full and considered discussion of this whole issue by the government in the particular context, of course, of the Black shareholding in John Fairfax, when the Treasurer said:

ANSWER.PARA: The Government will not countenance further increases in the permitted level of foreign involvement in mass circulation newspapers. There has not been and will not be any change to this policy.
I cannot be any clearer or more explicit than the Treasurer has been in this respect, and I believe Senator Panizza ought to take yes for an answer in that particular respect.

PARA.TAB: On this repeated reference by the opposition to the alleged nature of Prime Minister Keating's conversation with or commitment to Mr Black before the last election, let me just quote exactly what Prime Minister Keating said in Seattle last Thursday, 18 November, because those opposite keep on referring to it. The relevant passage of the transcript is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: . . . I had a conversation with him last year when John Hewson had offered him 50 percent equity in John Fairfax & Sons, and I said to him, "Oh, I wouldn't consider that." I would consider going to 25 percent, because his claim was that he couldn't run the business at 14.9 per cent; that he had just concluded that day, a meeting at the Opera House where he had been pilloried in running the business with 14.9 per cent, and I said, "Well, we'll think about it but we want a commitment from you that the paper will be balanced''.

What we were being told before was that there was nothing that the Prime Minister had said in Seattle about the particular subject matter of the Treasurer's statement in April—and that is the particular commercial consideration, the economic consideration, the business consideration which justified the increase from 14.9 per cent to 25 per cent. That was the centrepiece of the Treasurer's assessment and understanding of the situation; it was the centrepiece of the government's assessment and understanding of it in cabinet, as I have just said; and it was the centrepiece of Mr Keating's assessment and understanding of it, as he, Mr Keating himself, said in Seattle last week.

PARA.TAB: So what about those opposite quoting the full text of these things before going off on yet another outrageously misleading, politically vindictive, inaccurate and squalid campaign of a politically partisan kind. They cannot help themselves. It is about time they learnt that none of this is doing them any good out there.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. If I can cut into the argument between Senator Evans and Senator Alston, I simply ask the minister to answer my question: will he or will he not rule out the possibility of a further increase in the level of foreign ownership under any government led by Mr Keating? Could he just say yes or no.
—I have repeated the considered, explicit and straightforward statement by the Treasurer. I have nothing to add.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services. Last Thursday, when the Leader of the Opposition addressed the Australian conference of the Screen Production Association, he said that the government had no long-term policy for support of the film industry. What recent initiatives has the government taken to support this important industry; and does it intend, as implied by the Leader of the Opposition, to slash assistance over the next three years?

—To the extent that Dr Hewson, in the course of his address to the Screen Production Association, gave some indications of support to the film industry, I welcome that. I was a bit concerned that he appeared to be, once again, looking for a tax driven solution to funding the film industry. That would be a cause for concern but perhaps that will not happen. Perhaps it will not develop in that direction; I hope not. I was a little disappointed that in that context he used that forum, I think quite inappropriately, for a fairly partisan speech, at least in some part. I was particularly concerned because either the Leader of the Opposition was deliberately misleading in his speech or he has a very poor understanding of government accounting conventions. I do not think it is the latter.
—Option two.

—No, I think he understands. That is one thing I would say for him. I think he deliberately set out to create the wrong impression. He sought to create the impression that the government had made a decision to reduce its support to the industry in 1996-97 to below $20 million, whereas he knows that the government accounting conventions require the forward estimates to show a zero commitment for areas that are under review.

PARA.TAB: The budget for the forward period beyond the FFC contract—or any other, but, in this instance, where an agency is under review—requires that there is no budget allocation. The Leader of the Opposition knows that. Either he is saying that if he were leading a government the budget papers would contain figures even when they were under review, or he is saying that he would not have a review or that he does not know that a review is going on—it could be all three.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I raise a point of order. On the issue of relevance, the minister was asked about the government's policy in relation to the film industry. All he has done for the first two minutes of his answer is to attack John Hewson. I ask you either to make him answer the question or to sit him down.
—Order! As I heard the question, it referred to a speech made by the Leader of the Opposition but it then asked about government policy. As such, I have allowed it.

—Thank you, Mr President. As I understood it, I was asked by Senator Denman whether we were going to slash spending, as Dr Hewson said, and I am making it clear that what Dr Hewson said was deliberately misleading. I thank Senator Kemp for allowing me to emphasise it.

PARA.TAB: The budget papers make it absolutely clear to anybody who seeks to read them that FFC funding beyond 1995-96 is subject to review. Fortunately, I had the opportunity to clear up the deliberate misunderstanding which was generated, and I made it clear to that grouping that the outcome of that review would not be a zero outcome, although it is not for me at this stage to say what it will be; nobody knows.

There are a number of initiatives in the budget for the film industry, the most important of which, in my view, is the additional $3.5 million over four years to the AFC for script development and producer support. This year the Commonwealth will spend over $102 million on support of the film industry specifically, which is just over 30 per cent of the federal arts budget. It is inconceivable to me that any Australian government would not wish to provide assistance to enable the industry to flourish, to create jobs, to earn exports and to have the cultural as well as the economic benefits which would flow.

I should also point out that with that commitment for $100 million, while I welcome the things that Dr Hewson said in his speech that indicated a generalised commitment to support the film industry, he should realise, as the industry does—the industry is not stupid—that someone who is proposing to slash outlays by $5 billion or $10 billion cannot go round promising increases to everybody; the whole still equals the sum of the parts. My advice is: if those opposite want to build support in the arts industry, they should stop worrying about attacking us so much and try to develop a policy that somebody might actually be prepared to support.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Resources. I ask whether the minister could explain the meaning of the words in the national forest policy statement, agreed by the Commonwealth and all states with the exception of Tasmania, that:

QUESTION.PARA: Forest management agencies will avoid activities that may significantly affect those areas of old growth forest or wilderness that are likely to have high conservation value.

How does the minister reconcile this statement with the clear-felling of areas that have been identified as having World Heritage values and as National Estate areas? If clear-felling does not significantly affect old growth forests, what does?

TALK.START.PARA: —Under the national forest policy statement, the Commonwealth and all the state and territory governments—that is, except Tasmania—have agreed on a cooperative approach to ensure the protection of old growth forests and wilderness with a view to having a representative reserve system in place by 1995 for forests on public lands and by 1998 for private forested land. Progress in implementing this policy is well under way.

PARA.TAB: A joint subcommittee of the Australian and New Zealand Environment and Conservation Council and the Australian Forestry Council is developing criteria for a representative forest reserve system which is expected to be finalised around the end of this year. Once the criteria have been agreed, the Commonwealth and the states will act to ensure that a representative reserve system is in place.

As Senator Coulter has just pointed out, as part of this approach it was agreed that, until forest assessments are completed, forest management agencies will avoid activities that may significantly affect those areas of old growth forest or wilderness that are likely to have high conservation values. The Commonwealth is very keen to cooperate with the states to ensure that this does happen. However, this does not mean that all logging in old growth forests should stop; it recognises that some logging in old growth forests and wilderness areas is necessary to meet industry requirements during the transition to regrowth and plantations. Some environmentalists have claimed this to be a moratorium on old growth logging, but that is not the case.

The national forest policy statement was developed as a partnership between the Commonwealth, states and territories for the future management of Australia's public and private forests on a sustainable basis. Now, all of the areas on the World Heritage List, such as the southern forests of Tasmania, are protected from logging operations. Similarly, areas which have been formally nominated for World Heritage status, such as Fraser Island, are excluded from logging operations. In this regard, it should be noted that under the inter-governmental agreement on environment the Commonwealth will consult with the relevant state for any future areas nominated for World Heritage listing. This is consistent with the cooperative approach set out in the national forests statement.

In regard to National Estate areas, there are clear legislative requirements applying to consideration of proposed woodchip export approvals, which are designed to minimise environmental impacts. As I said in my statement, cabinet's view was that, in view of the opposition's intractable position of saying no to any proposal, the chances of getting legislation through the Senate, after long and protracted debate on a nuclear issue, were probably not good. The question was whether we could achieve a better outcome for nuclear science by a non-legislative route? —My question is addressed to the Minister for Family Services. I refer to recent media reports of the importation by Australia of blood products produced in Germany which may be contaminated with the AIDS virus. Can the minister advise the Senate whether any such products have been imported and what steps have been taken to deal with any possible risk?

—Yes, I am aware of this issue and I can reassure the Senate that there is no need for concern. Australia has a very high degree of self-sufficiency in the manufacture of blood and blood products and it also maintains very high standards in the regulation of imports. No whole blood or plasma was imported for use in Australia.

PARA.TAB: The concerns that exist relate to two unregistered products imported from Europe under the special access scheme. These were brought in to treat a very rare form of haemophilia. It is treated by what is called Factor IX. The special access scheme allows individual doctors or institutions to bring in products which have not been approved by the TGA, the Therapeutic Goods Administration, for the treatment of serious or life threatening illness. The use of such drugs is determined by the doctor and can only be supplied with the informed consent of the patient. This is particularly important because drugs brought in under the SAS scheme are essentially experimental, and the Commonwealth can give no assurance as to the quality, safety or efficacy of such usage.

The TGA has been assured that, of the two products imported from Germany, the first, Fibrin, was not manufactured from the contaminated plasma. Two batches of the second product, Immuno Factor IX, were prepared from plasma supplied by UB Plasma, one of the companies involved in the use of the contaminated blood, although there is no evidence that contaminated blood was actually used in preparing these batches. It must be emphasised that the possible contamination of blood products with HIV is considered very unlikely, particularly in the use of Immuno Factor IX, because the preparation of that product involves heat treatment and filtration which should ensure the product is virus free.

Both batches were used by the same medical specialist and he has confirmed that only two patients have been treated with the suspect products. The treating doctor has been required by the TGA to take any necessary action with regard to testing the patients for the presence of HIV virus.

This incident demonstrates the wisdom of the Australian policy of pursuing self-sufficiency in products derived from human blood or plasma. There is only one imported product on the Australian Register of Therapeutic Goods which has an active ingredient derived from blood. It is not involved in the contamination scare.

Australia's high degree of self-sufficiency and high quality in this area are very much a tribute to the Australian Red Cross and to the voluntary blood donation scheme which we have in this country. We are relying much more on altruism than on money.It is also important to recognise that Australia's management of AIDS is leading the world, and that includes our blood transfusion service.

—My question to the Minister for Transport and Communications relates to recent tragic accidents involving children alighting from and boarding school buses. Can the minister advise whether action is being taken to improve safety in the use of school buses and, if so, what measures are being implemented?

—The federal government is very conscious of the particular dangers that are being faced by Australian school children in their daily task of getting to and from school. I think all honourable senators would agree that it is particularly tragic that families should suffer the loss of young children travelling to and from school. This is an exercise which should be safe. The real tragedy is that most of the deaths—and there are a significant number of them; I think honourable senators may be surprised to know just how many—are completely avoidable.

PARA.TAB: Unfortunately, a common thread runs through these accidents and this indicates how completely avoidable they are. While there has been, I think rightly, a focus recently on the safety of school children while in a bus—that is, we are focusing on, for example, fitting seat belts to buses—the statistics show that without question the greatest dangers faced by school children are not when they are in the bus but when they are approaching or leaving it.

A report that has just been released by the Queensland parliament's travelsafe committee indicates how appallingly high the tragic loss of young life is when children are travelling to and from school. This report reveals that in the state of Queensland alone between 1986 and 1991 there were 54 fatalities involving school age children travelling to and from school—54 deaths of school kids in five years. A school bus was involved in 10 of those cases in which a child was killed, but only one of the fatally injured children was actually an occupant of a bus at the time of the accident.

Two recent fatal accidents—one in Sydney, where two children were hit, and, unfortunately, one only a week or so ago in my home town of Darwin—had the common thread of children running around the front of the bus before the bus had left the bus stop. Such children cannot be seen by traffic that is coming from behind. From personal observation, I can attest to the fact that both children and drivers seem to have a total disregard for the safety problems that occur at congested times of the day when children are arriving at school in the morning and leaving in the afternoon.

I have recently written to all state and territory transport ministers seeking their agreement to a joint national review of the dangers for school children in getting on and off school buses. The review will identify the existing measures that are being taken by the states and develop a national program building on those initiatives.

There are two common factors that contribute to this unnecessarily high number of kids being killed. The first is that children run in front of the bus after they get off. The second, often related to the first, is that the parents or the carers of these children wait on the side of road opposite the bus for the children to get off. There is often a combination of the kid running in front of the bus to the adult who is waiting on the opposite side of the road.

Tragically, a lot of these deaths could be avoided if parents would simply wait on the same side of the road as the bus for their kids to get off. This would avoid the problem of the child running in front of the bus in the first place and running to the parent. That child has eyes only for that parent and is completely ignorant of the traffic coming the other way. I hope this review will be completed in time to allow it to be considered by the transport ministers conference that will be convened early in the new year.

SPEECH.PARA: What we have seen today is yet another example of this government's willingness to say or do anything to justify itself and disguise the sordid nature of its political decision making. What those press releases and that answer—that utterly disingenuous answer—were saying was that somehow there was some high principle involved in this decision, that it was somehow to do with the national interest. PARA.TAB: In the event that Mr Keating judged that they had delivered, he was prepared to grant that increase. He is prepared to do precisely the same thing again. It is bad enough people like Senator Evans coming in here devoid of any shred of integrity when it comes to understanding the difference between proper decision making based on the national interest—

TALK.START.PARA: —You would know all about that.

—I would, because I have been sitting here watching people who no longer know the difference between right and wrong, who equate the national interest with the interests of the ALP and who do not think that there is anything to be ashamed of in saying to the whole of Australia, `We were prepared to make a judgment in the national interest depending upon whether this mob toe the line'. That is what it is about. It is basically turning Mayor Daley's Chicago into a model of propriety.

PARA.TAB: Those opposite have no understanding. I know the New South Wales Right was always devoid of political morality and prided itself on pragmatism, but to think that the infection has spread south of the border to people like Senator Evans, who no longer understand that there is anything wrong with the Prime Minister saying, `I will be the judge of what is fair. I will make very significant commercial decisions that affect the interests of media proprietors and all those who serve with them on the basis of our perception of fairness', when this bloke has a reputation for belting up on journalists at the drop of a hat, has no compunction about ringing people and abusing them and has no compunction about complaining whenever he sees an article which he disagrees with.

I would have thought that at least Senator Evans would have had the decency to come in here and admit what the Prime Minister was forced to admit. Quite clearly, he felt that he had no choice but to announce to the world that he had made an utterly repugnant decision. I am sorry that Senator Evans cannot do the same. (Time expired)

SPEECH.PARA: Extract from the Australian Financial Review, Sydney, 12 March 1993
Why Hewson should win

PARA.TAB: This newspaper supported Labor in two of the past three federal elections. It did so primarily because Labor, under the leadership of Mr Hawke and Mr Keating, appeared most likely to implement the reforms so badly needed by the Australian economy.
In this election, we are recommending a vote for the coalition, precisely because Dr Hewson is more prepared than Mr Keating to press on vigorously with that crucial reform process.
Indeed, after 10 years, Labor appears to have reached the limit of its ability to push reform past the stubborn resistance of the unions and other vested interests.

Micro-economic reform has almost stalled over the past year. The Government seems unable seriously to tackle the issue of labour market reform. It seems unable to cut through the gross, union-imposed inefficiency of the transport sector that still undermines the competitiveness of the industry.
Senator Cook's version of enterprise bargaining is a parody of labour market reform, in which only agreements by registered unions are accepted.

To the Government, enterprise bargaining is essentially an add-on to the award system. The opportunity for bargaining is strictly limited—and so, therefore, is the opportunity for genuine workplace productivity gains.

In his economic statement in the first week of the campaign, Mr Keating proclaimed the Government's commitment to continue micro-economic reform. However, the Prime Minister's "forward agenda" was just a restatement of the very modest initiatives of the preceding 12 months.

Mr Keating's formal policy statement two weeks later confirmed the disappointment. In the crucial area of land transport there was to be another committee: the National Transport Planning Task Force; in coastal shipping, which remains a drag on industry, there was to be yet another bribe for another round of gentle reform. And that was it.

Of course, there would be economic reform under Labor. Despite the pressure from the unions and sections of industry, Mr Keating has courageously stood by the Government's policy of tariff reform, which will see most tariffs fall to 5 per cent by 1996.
The pressure of lower tariffs and increasing import competition in the product markets will force more reform on the labour market and the rest of the economy.

However, Labor now seems to have settled into a strategy of doing the minimum: of simply trying to nudge the unions and the other vested interests in the right direction as the tide of competition carries everyone slowly along. That's not good enough.

Look at transport. A recent report for the Australian Business Council estimated that in water transport less than 50 per cent of the possible savings identified by the Industry Commission and other inquiries had been achieved.

The productivity on Australia's reformed waterfront is still less than New Zealand's. And while the Government boasts of the progress made by the coastal shipping industry, it dares not expose the industry to international competition, which is the real test.
In the railways, only a small fraction of the productivity gains identified by the Industry Commission have yet been made. In domestic aviation, there are still large barriers to competition.

There is a vast amount still to be done to make the economy more efficient and internationally competitive. And that task is urgent. Only fundamental reform of the economy will produce the long-term growth necessary to reduce the high underlying rate of unemployment.

The issue of economic reform is the most important of this election. It is more important than the popular issues of the campaign: the GST and Medicare and even the high level of recession-induced, or cyclical, unemployment. When the recession is long over, unemployment will still be well above 600,000 unless the structural problems of the economy are addressed.

For all its faults, Dr Hewson's Fightback package, with its commitment to reform of the tax system, the labour market and the products markets, represents a clear and compelling plan for the future. It is the same energetic commitment to the transform the Australian economy that once characterised Labor.
Clearly, it is time for a change of government.

SPEECH.PARA: Extract from The Age, 12 March 1993
Why the coalition should win tomorrow

PARA.TAB: The outcome of tomorrow's poll will not alter the challenges facing Australia in the final years of the 20th Century. In essence, these challenges involve managing profound but necessary change, change that is likely to reshape—is already reshaping—the nation. For all the talk that the 1980s was a decade of greed, selfishness and waste, it was nevertheless a time of transition when it became clear that the old ways of doing things could no longer be sustained. It became a matter of national consensus that if Australia was to remain a prosperous liberal democracy with rising living standards offering a brief future for its young people, Australians would have to embrace change. Rising living standards were not a national birthright. The notion that we could rely on commodity exports to finance the protection of inefficient manufacturing industries that were there to provide employment had proved to be a costly fantasy.

To its credit, for much of its decade in power, the federal Labor Government understood all this. It recognised the need for sweeping changes in the way the Australian economy was structured and that these changes would amount to nothing short of an economic revolution. Paul Keating will be judged well by history for the dominant part he played in that process. The deregulation of the financial system, the floating of the dollar, the opening up of the banking system to foreign competition were all designed to sweep away the idea that Australia could somehow isolate itself from the rest of the world and remain an economic backwater with its living standards maintained by selling stuff we dug out of the ground or grew on top of it. The steel-industry plan, the car-industry plan and the program of tariff cuts—among other reforms—were all part of an attempt by the Government to open up the Australian economy to what was clearly a new and, in some ways, harsher international economic environment. The Government also deserves credit for the tentative and often painfully small steps it took to reform the industrial relations system even though it did not do enough. For much of the `80s, there was a general consensus between Labor and the coalition that change was necessary. There was even agreement on the direction of that change. It was the means rather than the ends over which the parties differed.

The recession, with its toll of more than a million unemployed, ended that consensus. Since he became Prime Minister, Mr Keating has been much less committed to the program of reform than he was during the years when he was federal Treasurer and the intellectual driving force of the Government. The recession brought about a loss of nerve, an uncertainty about the direction in which Australia should be headed. In a sense, the watering down of Mr Keating's commitment to change explains why he has, throughout this election campaign, been a Prime Minister neither able to defend his record nor map out the direction in which he wants to take the country. Instead, he has fixed his sights on the coalition's proposed goods and services tax and has sought to invest it with a sinister and wide-ranging significance. The GST, according to Mr Keating, will be a cancer on Australian society. It will fundamentally change the Australian way of life. It is a malevolent, evil tax. Quite frankly, this is nonsense. The irony of this election campaign is that the GST is really in no way a vital ingredient of the coalition's Fightback proposals nor, indeed, would it be vital to any reform program. While the GST will allow some restructuring of the tax system, it is a change we could have done without at this time. If the coalition loses tomorrow, it will be because a minor part of its reform proposals became the main issue of the election campaign.

In fact, it is the proposed changes in Australia's industrial relations system that are central to Fightback, for it is in this area that Labor has proved to be most timid and in which change is now most urgent. Whatever the benefits of the Accords I to VII between the Government and the ACTU since 1983, and these are arguable, the industrial relations system remains outmoded and rigid. Enterprise bargaining, for all the lip-service given to it by the Government and the trade unions, remains the exception rather than the rule. We believe the coalition's proposed changes in industrial relations are sensible and necessary if the goal of making Australian industry internationally competitive is to be achieved. The move away from a centralised wage-fixing system to a system of individual contracts between employers and employees will probably mean in the long term that workers with skills that are in demand will be better off, while those with few or no skills will be worse off. But there is no real alternative that will produce what we now desperately need: more productive workplaces. Labor, with its ties to the trade union movement, is never likely to be able to force through these sorts of workplace changes. On that basis alone, we believe the coalition ought to form the next government.

There is another major reason why the coalition ought to win tomorrow. Changes of government should be a regular occurrence in any liberal democracy and, after a decade in power, Labor has, despite Mr Keating's best efforts, become a Government that has lost much of its appetite for reform and renewal. There are echoes in the choice facing Australians tomorrow of the choice a previous generation faced in 1961 when the Menzies Government, after 12 years in power, and in the middle of a recession, scraped home by one seat basically because of the shortcomings of the then Labor leader, Arthur Calwell. In retrospect, it probably would have been better for Australia had Labor won that poll and been given the chance to implement some of its reforms then. Instead, it sat on the Opposition benches for another decade and, when it came to power, set about making up for its 23 years of frustration by trying to transform Australia in a matter of days. The failures of the Whitlam Government can in part be attributed to that extra decade of debilitating powerlessness that Labor experienced on the Opposition benches.

Australia needs a government in the `90s that will maintain the momentum of change, that will continue the transformation of the economy begun by the Labor Government. There is still a long way to go. The goal of that transformation ought never to be lost sight of: an Australia that offers its young people real hope of a decent future. We believe that a coalition victory tomorrow will best serve that goal.

SPEECH.PARA: Extract from The Sydney Morning Herald—12.3.93
It is time for a change

Of the millions of words spoken during this marathon election campaign, none were truer than those uttered by the Prime Minister when he launched his policies. "When you wake up on March 14, whoever has won the election, there will still be unemployment. There will still be problems to solve," Mr Keating said. Throughout the campaign the Labor Party has been keen to play down the magnitude of those problems; the Coalition has often exaggerated them. Nevertheless they are real and none of the parties has convinced us they have all the answers. The question confronting voters tomorrow is which of the parties is the more likely to have the conviction to tackle those problems. And, just as importantly, which is more likely to possess the occasional humility to admit that policies proposed in Opposition or in the heat of an election campaign are not necessarily appropriate when confronted by the harsh realities of the government.

PARA.TAB: In answering these questions, Australians have cause to take heart. This has been a contest between two very intelligent and tough-minded men. Both have shown they are not the sort of leader who will shirk tough decisions. Mr Keating has already served Australia with distinction as Treasurer, as a guiding force in Mr Hawke's Government and as Prime Minister. If he loses on Saturday, history will certainly acknowledge the role he played in forcing his party to confront the realities of the broader scale, he has commenced the vital task of convincing Australians of the opportunities to be gained from becoming a more competitive country. Floating the dollar, the entry of foreign banks, reform of the taxation system, a controlled reduction in protection—these are just some of his achievements. And their significance, in the context of the traditionally cantankerous Labor Party, cannot be underestimated.

Dr Hewson, for his part, has united a party which had been debilitated for most of the past decade by the rivalry between the former leaders, Mr Howard and Mr Peacock. No-one can now argue, as was the case in the last few elections, that the Liberals stand for nothing. Fightback, an unmistakably Hewson program, has unified the party and has also cemented relations within the Coalition. Whoever wins tomorrow, we will have a Prime Minister who will lead, not follow.

SPEECH.PARA: Many problems

PARA.TAB: Strong leadership will be required to confront the economic realities facing Australia. While it is now clear that talk of a "double dip" recession is part of the hyperbole of the campaign, the economy is obviously stuck in a path of weak recovery. Economic growth must continue to be encouraged but extreme care has to be taken not to again overheat the economy. Real wages must continue to be restrained. The spark of new business investment we have seen lately must be fanned. Inflationary expectations must be kept down. The expanding national debt must be reined in. And the tangle of subsidies, tariff barriers and work practices, which impede the growth of our export industries, must continue to be dismantled. These are some of the problems about which Mr Keating spoke; regrettably neither party has been prepared to fully address them over the past five weeks.

Indeed, the fiscal stimulus implicit in the policies of both Labor and the Coalition have been such as to alarm the Governor of the Reserve Bank, Mr Fraser. In an unprecedented intervention, he warned last week that economic growth was unlikely to be strong enough to reduce the budget deficit at a sufficiently rapid pace. The new government, Mr Fraser said, would have to rethink its spending and taxation pledges or face a substantial increase in interest rates which would wipe out economic recovery. It has been said, not entirely facetiously, that voters should endorse the party which is more likely to break its promises.

Dr Hewson has insisted throughout the campaign that unemployment, not the Goods and Services Tax (GST), is the major issue of the campaign. As he rightly says, Labor has proposed no solutions which will help get the dole queues down quickly. The job creation projects of One Nation, about which Mr Keating has boasted, are certainly exaggerated and problematic. His central campaign pledge—to create half-a-million new jobs over the next three years—has been exposed as unlikely to make a dent in the unemployment rate. This is because the Australian Bureau of Statistics estimates the labour force will grow by at least this amount over the same period.

SPEECH.PARA: Faster reform

But Dr Hewson cannot claim any magic answer to unemployment either. The Coalition's assertion that Fightback will create two million jobs by the year 2000 has always lacked credibility and it is no credit to Dr Hewson that he has continued to peddle this claim when he knows it has no econometric foundation. The Coalition is on firmer ground, however, when it argues that its commitment to a faster pace of structural reform of the economy and to deregulation of the labour market will make the economy more efficient and will boost jobs in the long run.

PARA.TAB: While unemployment is the most pressing issue, it is the GST which has dominated the campaign. Dr Hewson's decision to give it such a high priority, at such a political cost, is puzzling. The Labor Government has undoubtedly exaggerated the impact that it will have on individuals. But the Opposition is also guilty of overselling its reform. The majority opinion of economists now appears to be that a GST, and the tax reforms that will accompany it, will have a small, beneficial effect on the efficiency of the economy. But it is no economic salvation.

Fundamental labour market reform, for example, probably offers greater scope for economic efficiency gains. Labor's Accord was an important factor in restraining real wages during the economy's boom years. What is now needed, as Labor itself has acknowledged, is a means of continuing this restraint in total wages while also delivering sharp productivity gains. Properly handled, the strategy of encouraging voluntary employment contacts, proposed under the Coalition's Jobsback policy, seems far more likely to deliver these gains than the slowly-paced enterprise bargaining approach of Labor.

Over the past decade, the Labor Party has overcome the traditional suspicion of the electorate and demonstrated that it can govern responsibly. Its legacy is impressive in many areas. It has been Mr Keating's misfortune to have taken the reins too late. Although he has tried hard to rejuvenate the Government, it is showing unmistakable signs of chronic fatigue. It is time for a change. Without endorsing all aspects of the Coalition's program, Dr Hewson and his team should be given the opportunity to tackle the many problems which will still confront us when we wake up on Sunday morning.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator McKiernan)—On behalf of the President and in accordance with the provisions of the Audit Act 1901, I present the Auditor-General's report No. 12 of 1993-94: Efficiency Audit—Administration of the 150% Taxation Incentive for Industry Research and Development—Department of Industry, Technology and Regional Development, Australian Taxation Office.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: This is an extremely important report because, as mentioned in the report, the rate of growth of research and development expenditure by Australian business is one of the fastest, if not the fastest, in OECD countries. Nevertheless, we are still 17th out of 24 OECD countries—that is, seventh from the bottom—for our expenditure on R&D by Australian businesses. The government's efforts to make sure we got further up the ladder resulted in the 150 per cent research and development tax incentive which was introduced for the six-year period from 1 July 1985 to 30 June 1991. There was a suggestion in 1991 that the rate should be continued until 30 June 1993 and then reduced to a rate of 125 per cent to apply until 30 June 1995. However, in August 1992 the government announced that the incentive would continue at the rate of 150 per cent in recognition of the fact that research and development is an important factor in increasing the export capacity of our industries, particularly in the area of innovation.

PARA.TAB: This report is extremely disturbing because it addresses the effectiveness of this tax incentive. The recommendations disclose that currently we do not know whether this incentive is functioning or whether it is providing the increased expenditure by business. We do not know because the two bodies that are responsible for it—the Industry Research and Development Board and the Australian Taxation Office—do not have proper procedures in place to monitor and assess the benefit that Australia derives from this incentive.

Recommendation 1 says that action should be taken to enable the Industry Research and Development Board and the department to acquire the relevant information which is necessary for them to discharge effectively their respective responsibilities under the tax concession scheme. Quite clearly, the information flow is inadequate at the moment. The two bodies agree that this should be improved.

Recommendation 2 states that the monitoring responsibility of the board is certainly not clear and that the department will seek authority to be able to monitor. Recommendation 3 suggests that there are no comprehensive assessment criteria for monitoring because the Auditor-General recommends that the board establish comprehensive assessment criteria.

Recommendation 4 suggests that the management information system currently is not adequate and that it should be improved. Again, the department agrees that this needs to be done, quite clearly admitting that the current management information system is simply inadequate.

Recommendation 5 suggests that the data processing needs need to be satisfied and that currently the data processing capacity is simply not adequate. Recommendation 6 suggests that the data management for tax assessment requires amendments so that retrospective claims for concessions can be processed.

I could continue: I have notes for recommendations 7, 8, 9, 10, 12, 13, 14, 15, 16 and 17 which indicate that neither of those bodies currently has the capacity to assess whether this particular tax concession produces the results that we should expect from it. There are also 17 recommendations—starting with recommendation 18—which address work practices in both the department and the Taxation Office. To a large extent these recommendations also address their capacity to provide a reasonable assessment of where we are going.

This report must be of very great concern, disclosing as it does the fact that, despite the considerable number of years that this tax concession has been available and its having cost the taxpayer in the order of $300 million a year, the government departments administering it do not have the capacity to assess—and clearly, therefore, have not done so during all those years—the extent to which it actually produces the result of increasing expenditure on research and development and whether the expenditure on research and development, to the extent that it is undertaken, actually produces results in assisting our industries to become more competitive in international markets.

I believe it is a scandalous situation. Obviously, action is long overdue. I suggest that the government take action to ensure that both of these bodies take action as quickly as possible. I also suggest that the Minister for Science and Small Business (Senator Schacht) take responsibility to provide the Senate, very quickly, with a progress report on the action that has been taken.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCHACHT
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Science and Small Business and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —In view of Senator Spindler's comments and his motion to take note of the Auditor-General's report, I think a response is warranted from me, as minister in this chamber responsible for the industry portfolio. I want to assure Senator Spindler that I and the Minister for Industry, Technology and Regional Development, Mr Griffiths, take this report very seriously, because we believe that the 150 per cent tax concession is a very important part of the development of Australian industry.

PARA.TAB: Senator Spindler has noted, and it is noted in the report, that it is no longer a program that has a sunset clause on it. It is now accepted by the government as an indefinite program. We, and industry, are delighted to have it accepted as an ongoing program as a feature of our support for R&D in Australia. We note that the report says that there is a difficulty in making a true assessment of the value of this program so far. All I can say is that in my time as Minister for Science and Small Business, going to many functions involving industry, small business and the scientific community, this program of 150 per cent tax deduction is very strongly supported. In fact, many industries now tell us that if it were not for the tax deduction they would not have increased the level of R&D. They tell us that, as a result of this concession, they are able not only to increase their R&D expenditure but also to get a commercial outcome as a result of their R&D expenditure that leads to extra goods and services being produced in Australia, extra income for the economy and jobs.

We accept that in the time the scheme has been going it has not been able to be measured according to perfect economic theory. I suppose that some so-called economic rationalists might like to have a clear-cut theoretical cost-benefit analysis done of such a scheme. We would like that done as well. However, I think it needs more time before someone can come up—

TALK.START.PARA: —How many more years, Minister?

—I am not in any way decrying the scheme. If someone can come up with a theoretical formula to measure the cost-benefit we get as a community directly from the tax deduction, we would welcome it. But that is always going to be difficult because of some assumptions, the true measurement of the lead times and so on.
—The recommendations are there and they only need to be followed to rectify the problems.

—I accept that. Again, I emphasise that Minister Griffiths and I accept that this is a very important report. We will respond to it after careful consideration. We do not want the 150 per cent tax deduction for R&D losing its credibility or being open to challenge through supposed difficulties of administration. The value of the scheme would be affected and people could use as an excuse to undermine the scheme, to try to get rid it, the cost-benefit analysis and so on. I can assure Senator Spindler that, in Minister Griffiths and me, he has two strong devotees of the scheme. I can also assure him that all the anecdotal evidence we have from around industry is that there is very strong support for it.

PARA.TAB: As minister for small business, I get many queries raised, with people wanting the cut-in point lowered so that it is easier for small business to get R&D measured and accepted for the 150 per cent tax deduction. I also get requests that the definition of R&D be expanded into assistance for some aspects of marketing. These are all issues that have been raised with us because, overwhelmingly, industry accepts that it is a very valuable tool.

One of the points raised in the report which Senator Spindler has mentioned is the conflict of responsibility of officers in both DITARD and the Australian Taxation Office. The ATO believes that providing the information that DITARD officers would like to have to properly assess the scheme, providing transparent information about its success and about improving the scheme, could be in breach of the Income Tax Assessment Act's secrecy provisions.

According to the report—and we welcome this—these shortcomings and this difficulty have been dealt with and overcome. We hope that is correct. We want to follow that through. If it means that we can therefore have better information available to us to improve the management of the scheme and understand in a more defined way how it is working, that will add to the value of the scheme itself.

I know Senator Spindler's interest in the industry portfolio and industry development. We accept that this is a major report that has to be considered very seriously and we will respond to it accordingly. Minister Griffiths and I are very strongly committed to ensuring that this 150 per cent tax deduction for R&D continues in Australia.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
