When we talk about those grants that were made in November of last year—that is, just a few months before the federal election—we are talking about an allocation by the minister of many millions of taxpayers' dollars to benefit certain sporting or cultural or recreational clubs in relation to their facilities. That, on the face of it, might not seem extraordinary. The question is the basis upon which Mrs Kelly chose one applicant over another.

What has come out in very recent times as a result of the Auditor-General's findings is that, extraordinarily, it was Labor seats, which accounted for 53 per cent of the House of Representatives, which received 73 per cent of the number of grants and 66 per cent of the value of those grants. Also, on average, the total value of grants to a Labor-held seat was $257,000 and, to a coalition seat, only $141,000—almost half. On average, the total value of grants to a marginal Labor-held seat was $326,000 and, to a marginal coalition seat, $163,000—again, almost double the grant went to the Labor-held marginal seat.

The question is: was that purely coincidental or was there some political bias, as one would tend to suspect with such extraordinary figures? What is most disturbing is that the Auditor-General was unable to find, from the documents available, the basis upon which she chose one applicant over another. What we do know is that she signed the letters for those who were successful; the department signed letters for those who were unsuccessful. We know the department sent her a schedule, divided into three, of those applicants who were more demanding than others, but the department was then not told of the basis on which she made the final decisions.

We also know, rather interestingly, that she asked the department for details of the electorates within which each grant application was located. How that could be relevant in her determination? Interestingly, the department, to its credit, was not prepared to provide that information until she requested it in writing, so one suspects that the department was suspicious that something unsatisfactory was going on.

As the Auditor-General said, the public of Australia has the right to know the basis upon which applicants were deemed to be found successful or unsuccessful. The most appropriate body in this parliament to get to the bottom of this mess, on the basis of historical experience, is the estimates committee of this parliament. It did not consider this particular matter because the Auditor-General's report came out a few days after the closing date for notice that would have got the matter before the supplementary hearings of Estimates Committee E. It therefore seems to be sensible that that committee is now able to reconvene and question the minister and the bureaucrats on the basis on which these grants were given and why one applicant was successful over another.

This committee could very efficiently deal with this particular matter, get to the bottom of it, and either remove the doubt that is in the public eyes at the moment that the minister has acted improperly and treated this public money simply as a slush fund, or find that that was, in fact, the case. I move the suspension of standing orders in order that we can debate the principal motion and get this matter off to Estimates Committee E to have it dealt with properly. (Time expired)

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCHACHT
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Science and Small Business and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —The government opposes this motion to suspend standing orders so that Senator Hill's notice of motion No. 438 to reconvene Estimates Committee E can be debated. There has been a very lengthy debate and discussion in the last few days in both houses of this parliament about this issue. Mrs Kelly, as the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories, has responded openly to all the accusations. She has made it quite clear that she is happy to cooperate with the National Audit Office on all aspects of its review. She has also announced that there will be a review of the program, because it runs out at the end of this financial year.

PARA.TAB: I would have thought there is a very good case for the government to consider continuing the program for another period because of the success of the program and the way it has been welcomed in the local communities to get their community facilities enhanced, whether they be cultural, community or sporting. None of the bodies which have had a grant made to them, whether they be in a Labor or Liberal held electorate, have been ringing up or publicly saying, `We want you to take the money back. We want you to dismantle the facility provided under this program'.

First of all, we do not have community outrage about this program. We have opposition outrage because, in its conspiracy mode, it is trying to find another reason to justify to its own supporters how it lost the election—the unlosable election. Suddenly it is this program that is the justification.

I have looked through some of the details of where these programs have been issued. Interestingly enough, many of them were provided to electorates that changed hands at the last election. In my own state of South Australia there were programs in Hindmarsh, Grey and Adelaide.

TALK.START.PARA: —You still tried to get them.

—If those grants were as effective as Senator Knowles thought, under the conspiracy theory those opposite are putting forward and with their paranoid minds that would have meant that we would have held those seats. But they still changed. Seats were lost in South Australia despite having some grants made to those programs.

PARA.TAB: This suspension of standing orders is absolutely unnecessary not only because a review is now being conducted by Minister Kelly's own department about this program, but also because agreement has been reached that the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Environment, Recreation and the Arts has had the audit report referred to it for examination.

TALK.START.PARA: —And who chairs that!

—It is chaired by John Langmore but Liberal Party members of the House of Representatives also serve on that committee. Is Senator Knowles saying that the Liberal House of Representatives members are not as good as Liberal senators in asking questions? Is she trying to say to her colleagues in the House of Representatives who sit on that committee that they are not as good as Liberal senators? I would like her to go down and try to say that they are all tame cats, they are all pussy cats and they are all wimps in asking questions. It is an hilarious accusation for Liberal senators to be making against the Liberals in the House of Representatives that they are not good enough at asking questions. I am sure that some of them would like to prove that they do not have to be as rude as Bronwyn Bishop in asking a question to prove how effective they are.

PARA.TAB: This political stunt is absolutely unnecessary. A House of Representatives standing committee on which opposition members are represented is dealing with it. A review committee is also dealing with it departmentally. It does not mean that there cannot be further questions asked and debated in this place or further resolutions. To refer it to Estimates Committee E is just a political stunt and ought to be dismissed accordingly.

TALK.START.PARA: —I find the contribution by the Minister for Science and Small Business (Senator Schacht) nothing short of continual appalling nonsense. To think that he can stand in this place and pretend that some inquiry down in the House of Representatives where the Labor Party has the numbers—he consistently refused to answer my interjections on that—where, because the government does not want the scrutiny—
—We have the numbers on the estimates committee.

—I know you do, Senator Schacht, the clot. What I am saying is that Senator Schacht is trying desperately to hide the situation from the scrutiny that the estimates committees can do best. He knows only too well what Minister Kelly has done in this exercise. In his contribution today he has not been able to defend her in one instance. He says, `Oh, but we lost some of those seats'. That did not stop the government pork-barrelling those seats at the same time. Let me just give the Senate an example of some of the pork-barrelling that went on in my state of Western Australia. The government pork-barrelled Canning, $198,250; Brand, $164,720; Fremantle, $260,500; Perth, $120,000; Swan, $265,000; and Stirling, $270,000.
—And we still lost.

—Labor still lost it, but the government gave it its best shot by pork-barrelling it. Let us look at the electorate of Moore; it got $60,000, and yet the government pork-barrelled Stirling $270,000. That is just absolute nonsense.

PARA.TAB: Minister Kelly has failed to administer her department; she has failed to administer the guidelines; she has failed in every department. The blatant pork-barrelling into these Labor marginal seats is just unforgivable. At no stage under repeated questioning last week in the House of Representatives, again today, and in a further debate today, has she even been able to produce the documents. What is more sinful is that the Auditor-General went in there to try to find the documents and could not find them.

The background against which these decisions were made had to be documented somewhere. Has this minister, in this chamber, stood up here and explained why there are no documents? No. Has Minister Kelly in the other place explained why there are no documents? One might ask: has she shred the documents? Has she got rid of them? If not, where are they? If they are still in existence, why will she not produce them?

TALK.START.PARA: —Ah.
—There is no point in Senator Schacht just sitting over there and going `Ah' like some contorted fool; he has to somehow say where those documents are.

PARA.TAB: Minister Kelly is unable to answer any of the questions; she is unable to answer any of the questions that have been put to her by the Auditor-General as to what the decision-making process was. The simple point is that the report also stated that there was insufficient consultation; that the projects were not monitored systematically; that certain administrative procedures left the program open to fraud; that the program fraud control was out of date; and that there was poor performance information. This is the report of the independent Auditor-General on this incompetent minister who cannot for some reason find the documentation on which these decisions were made.

If this government wants to continue this absolute and utter misuse of taxpayers' funds, it is about time it put itself forward again for the scrutiny of estimates E, got off its tail and found these documents, or got Mrs Kelly to resign. This is not the first time Mrs Kelly has been proven to be incompetent, it certainly will not be the last, but what is she hiding from the parliament on this occasion? If the Liberal Party had not brought this to light when Senator Baume, as the then shadow minister in this area, asked the Auditor-General to find out the basis on which these decisions were made, nothing of this would have come out. Yet here we have again this Labor Party trying to defend the indefensible. Let us face it, it has used taxpayers' money to try to win its way back into government.

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I begin by saying that the Australian Democrats are more than happy to support this motion at the moment. We believe this is a very important issue and one that should be debated. Listening to the debate so far, it seems that most speakers have, indeed, raised a lot of the substantive matters. So, hopefully, the undertaking which I understand was given that we would not blow this out for the rest of the day will be adhered to and both motions can be put fairly quickly. As other people have gone to the substantive issue, I will do so as well and, therefore, hopefully reduce the need for this matter to be discussed at all between the two motions being put.

PARA.TAB: Firstly, it is most disappointing to hear honourable senators reflecting on a House of Representatives committee. Surely, we should see this as part of the process of leaving it firstly to the House of Representatives committee, which is up and ready to go—Mr Langmore has given an undertaking that it will indeed be starting this year—and giving it the chance to collect the documents and talk to people, as it is planning to do. Then those who go into estimates next year will be well and truly armed with all the material they need if there are still further questions to be asked. I reject the idea that it is all a matter of numbers on the committee in the House of Representatives. I believe that the information will speak for itself; indeed, much of the information that is within this report speaks for itself.

In particular, I am concerned with the item 2.20, on page 11, where comments are made about advisers who are put between the permanent Public Service and the responsible minister. I understand that some of those people will be called to give evidence to the House of Representatives committee. That is not to say that ministers should not employ such staff but that, if such staff exercise power, they too should be held publicly accountable for the exercise of that power. I am sure that the House of Representatives committee will look at the holding to account of those people and that will be required to produce all the documentation they have.

The Democrats will not be supporting the recall of Estimates Committee E with all its additional expense and the time that that would involve when we have a large number of very important issues before this house.

TALK.START.PARA: —What a wimp!

—Senator Panizza will have that opportunity next year. Once we have the bulk of the documentation—hopefully all of the documentation—as we move towards estimates next year, there will be sufficient time for him to go ahead if he wants further details and information and do that.

—I rise to oppose the motion to suspend standing orders so that Senator Hill can move his motion to reconvene Estimates Committee E. It is impossible to conclude that this motion has been moved in any genuine spirit of inquiry. It is yet another gigantic trawling exercise by the opposition; it is another example of political driftnet fishing. That is what those opposite have been reduced to doing. It is also reflective of the style of politics which has crept into our system over the last weeks and months whereby the personal vendetta replaces other kinds of political approach. We have seen it repeatedly with the Prime Minister (Mr Keating), but we now see it directed against Mrs Kelly and I, for one, find that distasteful.

PARA.TAB: The exercise to which the chamber has been made an attendant observer this afternoon is nothing more than another example of political frustration. While I am more than happy to defend Mrs Kelly at length and in detail, I will try to confine my remarks to the actual mechanics involved in what Senator Hill is endeavouring to do. What he is really proposing is that we have a continuing closed loop of politics—that is, that we have the estimates committees continually sitting all year around, in duplication and in waste. There are any other number of bodies, whether they be in the House or the Senate, that can do a job and confront a task more than adequately.

The problem we have at the moment with this coalition is that its members have been out of power for so long they have no concept of how public money ought to be applied and spent—none whatsoever. For example, if we look at the piece by Laurie Oakes in the Bulletin this week, or last Saturday evening's Order in the House, we will see that it is becoming increasingly clear there is now a definite, genuine and legitimate focus on the manner in which the coalition in opposition abuses the committee system. Senator Hill's proposition is yet another step in the process of abuse.

Tomorrow, Estimates Committee A will be meeting to look at yet another request for an estimates committee to come back; having already been through its hearings and its supplementary hearings, there now is yet another coalition proposition for us to come back. Again, more public money would be simply disappearing down the drain as a consequence of coalition indulgence.

There is no way in the world that the Australian electorate will elect to the office of government a group of people acting in this way. I know it is fine for a few cheap laughs and a few cheap headlines day to day—that may have happened for a while—but the editorials for the last week or so have begun to turn against those opposite as well. For example, the Telegraph Mirror in Sydney has even referred to the performances of Senator Hill and Senator Kemp. We have a whole series of indications that the public mood has shifted. I must say that I found the attack on Mrs Keating and the Keating children at the Lodge absolutely appalling, and it is appropriate that that ought to be said in the chamber.

This coalition is the most negative opposition grouping in the history of the Commonwealth. It is obstructive and it is destructive. There is no alternative opposite—there is no alternative series of views, no alternative opinion, no alternative platform, no alternative framework of government. It is entirely lacking. What has happened to those opposite, courtesy of Dr Hewson, is that they have gone from a position with Fightback—and I know they all recoil at the mention of the word—

TALK.START.PARA: —Great policy.
—`Great policy' says Senator Herron. Does he still embrace it? Does the surgeon-general, for whom I have great respect, still embrace Fightback?
—They all still embrace it.
—For goodness sake, `Great policy' says Senator Herron. Let us have that in Hansard; that will be more than valuable.

PARA.TAB: Having been rejected a fifth time by the Australian electorate, those opposite have gone from a position where they had in Fightback chapter, verse, clause and footnote on everything to a situation where they do not have a policy on anything. They do not have a policy on Mabo or industrial relations. They sneer at APEC. They said the Cambodian peace initiative could not succeed.

They have a policy and a platform on absolutely nothing, so all they can do is spend their time muckraking. This is entirely devoid of any purpose or objective. It is an absolute exercise in sterility. The manner in which those opposite behave reminds me of the T.S. Eliot poem The Hollow Men—the hollow men and women of the coalition. I am delighted that the Democrats are opposed to the proposition, for good and legitimate reasons. So is the government. The motion for the suspension of standing orders ought to be defeated.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tierney Sen J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the motion for the suspension of standing orders moved by Senator Hill and to urge this chamber to recall Estimates Committee E to consider, in particular, the very serious matters that have been raised in the Auditor-General's report. What we have before us is yet another case of how this government rorted its way to an election victory. It is hard to find people who admit that they voted for the Labor Party. One of the reasons is the rorts that were going on; one relates to the electoral system, which we are uncovering in a committee at the moment; another is the outrageous lies that the government told in lying its way to the election; and here we have an example of blatant pork-barrelling right around the Commonwealth.

PARA.TAB: The government has actually given a new meaning to the term `triennial grants'. It granted $29.5 million to this program just before the election. Guess what happened in this budget? It disappeared totally. People were saying what a great program it was earlier on. If it was such a great program, why has it disappeared? I predict that it will come back in 1995—in time for the next election.

What happened before this election was that in November all the grant applications were due and in February—surprise, surprise—they were all allocated. Labor seats received 73 per cent of the grants. Marginal Labor seats received double that received by the coalition seats. Labor marginals received $326,000; coalition marginals received $163,000. If anyone wanted to investigate this, there is some factor operating there. Why is it biased one way and not the other?

Let us look at an example. Logan City is an example of how this bias worked in a particular way to favour Labor in the election. An amount of $96,000 was given to the Logan City workers, rugby and sporting club. One might ask: what is wrong with that? At the time the grant was made the so-called club did not have a playing field and did not even have a team, yet it got $96,000. I was listening to Mrs Kelly today in the other chamber. In response to a question from Dr Hewson, she said, in terms of the guidelines, that it must be for the upgrading of existing facilities. If one does not have a playing field to start with, one has a massive upgrade to do. This is an example of blatant pork-barrelling by this government before the election.

If we look at what the Australian National Audit Office said in relation to this sort of blatant pork-barrelling, we see that it brings out some areas of very serious concern, which Senator Loosley was trying to sweep under the carpet. Indeed, in the other chamber Mrs Kelly spent most of her time going through the objectives of the program and the procedures that were followed. The Australian National Audit Office said:

SPEECH.PARA: the procedures for processing applications were poor. Details on applications were not checked and necessary documentation was not followed up where it was missing
projects were not monitored systematically to ensure completion or achievement of program objectives
. . . the program open to fraud and the program fraud control plan was out of date,
there is poor performance information.

The Auditor-General then went on to outline his very serious doubts—doubts which I believe this government should take particular note of and that is why we want Estimates Committee E recalled. The ANAO noted:

. . . some anomalies in the approval of grants . . . by the Minister but was unable to resolve them because the reasons for decisions were not accurately documented. For the same reason claims that decisions on the allocation of grants were politically motivated could not be put to rest.
That is interesting wording. That is bureaucratese for the fact that this has been—

TALK.START.PARA: —You hardly asked a question about it. A couple of questions on estimates and those were on the republic and David Hill.

—If we had had this information, we would have asked a lot of questions at that time. We did not have it. We have it now and we have had a look at it. It raises very serious doubts, so let us ask some questions about it. It is interesting to note that the Auditor-General also said:

SPEECH.PARA: The role of the Minister's staff in the selection of grants appears significant.
We should recall Estimates Committee E to consider these matters. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: West Sen S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —As the chairman of Estimates Committee E, I have no great recollection of any length of questioning by the opposition on this particular issue. The opposition just completely avoided it. It was far more interesting for Senator Ian Macdonald to ask why there were no Queensland members on the ATC. It was not as if we stifled debate in this particular estimates committee.

PARA.TAB: In fact, in an article in yesterday's Canberra Times I was criticised for allowing Senators Kemp and Alston to question Mr Hill from the ABC, which they did for 2 1/2 to three hours, on the basis that I did not stop them and make them be more relevant to the estimates procedure. The criticism was that the hearing was rambling and out of control because of the questioning by Senators Kemp and Alston.

The whole situation is that you are damned if you do and damned if you do not. If one allows members of parliament to ask the questions that they think are appropriate, one is damned by the media for giving them that right of free choice and speech. If one then says, `Hey, you should have asked some questions when you had the opportunity, and you now want to have another go at it', one is still in strife. One cannot win. Laurie Oakes's article in the Bulletin of November 23 stated:

With millions of dollars of taxpayers' money at stake, the time may be ripe for a review of the whole senate committee system. Somebody needs to watch the watchdogs. It is not only public servants who should be accountable for waste and inefficiency and indulgent behaviour.

SPEECH.PARA: That is obviously the situation in this case. In fact, for five hours during the supplementary estimates hearings Senator Ferguson was the only opposition senator who deigned to make an appearance. Two of the others chose that week to go off with a committee somewhere else. (Time expired)

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator McKiernan)—Order! The time for this debate has expired.
Question put:
That the motion (Senator Hill's) be agreed to.
Question so resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate having decided that the matter is urgent and suspended standing orders, I move:

PARA.TAB: That General Business notice of motion no. 438 standing in his name for this day, relating to the reconvening of Estimates Committee E, may be moved immediately and have precedence over all other business until determined.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: (1)That, notwithstanding anything contained in standing orders, Estimates Committee E reconvene as soon as practicable to reconsider the estimates of the Department of Environment, Sport and Territories in the light of the significant reservations concerning aspects of the department's expenditure expressed by the Auditor-General in Efficiency Audit Report No. 9, 1993-94, entitled `Community Cultural, Recreational and Sporting Facilities Program', tabled in the Senate on 16 November 1993.
(2)That the committee report to the Senate on or before 6 December 1993.

SPEECH.PARA: I move this motion in the hope that the Senate will now agree that the most appropriate method of financial accountability—the tried and tested method, the estimates committee—be permitted to be utilised to get to the bottom of this very serious concern that has been uncovered by the Auditor-General.

PARA.TAB: I was astounded that the attitude of the Australian Democrats in the previous debate, on the suspension of the standing orders, appeared to be that they would not support the reconvening of the estimates committee. This is the party, of course, that said that it was here to keep the bastards honest, which we always presumed meant the government; yet when we move in this place to allow the Senate committee—the most appropriate committee—to simply hold a day's hearing to examine these very serious revelations of the Auditor-General, the Australian Democrats say, `No, we won't permit you to do that. We will not permit the Senate to look at these very serious concerns raised by the Auditor-General in his report'.

I turn to the problem which was raised by Senator West as to the reason why the committee did not look at this matter when it met a few weeks ago. Of course, as I indicated, the reason was that the Auditor-General's report was put down a few days after the closing of the time by which we would have had to give notice of this line of questioning. So this is the first opportunity we have had to enable and facilitate the committee to meet its responsibility; that is, to be called and, in turn, to call the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories (Mrs Kelly) and the bureaucrats to get to the bottom of this very serious matter—and it is a very serious matter.

I understand that since this scheme was established there have been some four allocations of money. We are talking about some $60.3 million of taxpayers' money that has been disbursed to sporting, cultural and recreational bodies at the apparent discretion of the minister. That is a very large sum of taxpayers' money. All we are seeking to do is to take up the challenge of the Auditor-General and to try to find out the basis upon which the minister has allocated the money to certain applicants over others.

I put to the Senate a few minutes ago when speaking to the motion to suspend standing orders the fact that, coincidentally or otherwise, it seems that these grants that were made just before the federal election were biased very much in favour of applicants from Labor Party electorates—almost to a ratio of two to one in dollar terms.

That, not surprisingly, was regarded with some disquiet by the Auditor-General, who then sought the documentation which was the basis of the minister's decision regarding allocation. The minister then referred the Auditor-General back to the department. The Auditor-General had already seen the documents in the department and, therefore, advised the Australian public that there was nothing on the record in the department that indicated why the minister chose one applicant over another.

The Auditor-General's view was, quite clearly, that the minister should have to demonstrate why one good cause was regarded as of greater value than another good cause, why it was that so many of these good causes were apparently within Labor Party electorates, and why the Labor Party therefore had the benefit of a huge sum of taxpayers' money immediately before the election.

Is it unreasonable that, in those circumstances, circumstances of major disquiet brought to the attention of the parliament by the Auditor-General, the estimates committee should not be reconvened for a day's hearing to do that job which it does well; that is, to examine the minister and the bureaucrats, get to the bottom of this matter and seek to answer some of those questions that have been left unanswered by the Auditor-General because the Auditor-General has not been able to get the documents? Is it unreasonable that the Senate should be permitted to fulfil the function that it has fulfilled so well over the years?

We are not talking about great expense to the taxpayers in the scrutiny function; we are really talking about a day's hearing. As I said, when one compares that with the some $60-odd million that has been appropriated to these programs by the government, a day's hearing by a committee that is skilled and experienced in this task is not unreasonable. It would not need any longer. It would meet next week and, as we say in the motion, it would report to the Senate on 6 December. On the first sitting day in the next sitting week, the committee could report to the Senate and the Senate would then be able to address the questions that were left unanswered by the Auditor-General.

The argument that cost is a barrier simply does not stand analysis. Senator West argued that point. The argument that the Senate should have looked at it earlier is also not an argument because, as we found out, the Auditor-General's report was, in fact, put down thereafter. The argument that a committee of the House of Representatives is also looking at this matter does not really stand scrutiny because that does not excuse us from our responsibility in this place.

TALK.START.PARA: —It never does with you lot. It never does.

—The Australian Democrats are not in the House of Representatives. They say that they have come here to keep the bastards honest, yet when they have an opportunity to do so, what do they do? They wash their hands of it and say, `Oh, it was a ministerial slush fund—$30 million given to Labor Party causes. We are not going to inquire into that'. If they are not prepared to inquire into that, what are they prepared to inquire into? What useful purpose do they serve in this Australian parliament if they have washed their hands of the scrutiny function—the function to keep the government financially honest?

PARA.TAB: It is amazing that the Democrats would come in here and have the nerve to say, `We accept the responsibility, but in this instance we are not going to exercise it. We are going to wash our hands of it'. The minister is apparently going to be able to get away with disbursing this huge sum of money without having to account to either the Auditor-General or the parliament for the basis upon which she has done it.

I ask the Australian Democrats to reconsider their position and allow this chamber in its scrutiny function to perform that which it does well. I ask the Western Australian Greens to do likewise because, sadly, they were not even prepared to vote for the suspension of standing orders that allowed us to move this substantive motion. I will be interested to hear from the Greens the reason they are apparently not prepared to support the estimates committee fulfilling its function. I likewise ask Senator Harradine, who is here. I trust that he will at least give us support in recognising that what we are asking to occur is simply what the estimates committees were designed to do; that is, to meet—

TALK.START.PARA: —And hardly ever do.

—If Senator Collins is complaining about their function, here they are. They are set up to meet with the minister and the department and scrutinise public expenditure. This committee should seek the basis upon which the minister allocated this very large sum of public money and therefore put to rest the concerns that have been raised by the Auditor-General that perhaps there was political bias in her decision making.

PARA.TAB: She did not provide the information to the Auditor-General. The Senate now has a responsibility to get that information in order that the public can be assured that she is not abusing her responsibility and disbursing public money in a way that demonstrates political bias. As I said, it is not much that we ask. All we ask is that the Senate be allowed to function in the way that it was designed to function and that we be allowed to meet our responsibilities in relation to financial scrutiny of this government's program.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will be brief because, as is normal with these debates, most of the substantive issues were canvassed during the debate on the motion to suspend standing orders, so I do not see any need to delay the Senate unnecessarily by canvassing those same arguments again.

PARA.TAB: The government will certainly be opposing this motion. Minister Kelly herself has indicated that she has commissioned a comprehensive review of all of these matters with her own department—the program, of course, comes to an end at the end of this year, in any case—but also a reference has been given to the appropriate House of Representatives committee. The chairman of that committee has already made a statement saying that the committee will deal with the matter expeditiously. Why the Senate needs to duplicate that—the minister of course is in the House of Representatives—is a strange indictment of the capacity of the opposition members who are on that committee.

I might point out some of the points that have been made that I find passing strange. The government has a majority on both the estimates committee and the House of Representatives committee. That has never prevented the proper scrutiny of these affairs, which will stand or fall on their own merit, I might add, irrespective of what report the committees bring down. The opposition members of those committees are quite capable of bringing down dissenting reports, which is their wont, but all of the issues will be canvassed publicly and that is the key issue. No matter what the report says, we are dealing with the question of public accountability. That will happen in that House of Representatives committee.

People talk about the estimates committee. I do not know how Senator Hill can talk about the professionalism of Senate estimates committee with a straight face. My view is that the way Senate estimates committees are handled is one of the great scandals of this chamber and that is a view I have had from the first time I attended one in old Parliament House. I can see that many efforts—

TALK.START.PARA: —It's the chairmanship.

—That interjection reveals the hypocrisy of those opposite: you are damned if you do, and damned if you don't. If the chairs of Senate estimates committees attempt to bring back the examination and scrutiny of those committees to the estimates—the committees are hardly ever used for that, in my experience—they are condemned outright by members of the opposition for trying to hide the truth or trying to cover things up and we then get the issue visited in this chamber. If the chairs of those committees try to be half reasonable, as Senator West was, they are then pilloried for not discharging their responsibilities.

PARA.TAB: Senator Tierney asks how I dare criticise the operation of Senate estimates committees. The chair should have been more rigorous, says Senator Tierney, in bringing senators into line. What a load of nonsense! In my experience—it has been of some years now, both as minister and as a government member of Senate estimates committees—that when the chairs try to do that, they are instantly pilloried by people like Senator Tierney for attempting to prevent senators from asking questions.

A classic example that I recall only too well—I have never forgotten it because it was one of the most substantial budget variations in my portfolio to come before an estimates committee—is the $100 million that we put into Aussat. That was one of the biggest supplementary estimates variations to a portfolio that I have seen. One would have thought that it would have justified a question or two at a Senate estimates committee.

I have never forgotten the night at the Senate committee where Senator Walters from Tasmania—there were others, but it was Senator Walters primarily—spent four hours grilling the officers of the ABC about why the ABC had broadcast the program The Riddle of the Dead Sea Scrolls on Palm Sunday—a matter which had absolutely nothing to do with the Senate estimates. Hours and hours were spent on that point at that Senate estimates committee.

If Senator Tierney is going to pillory the chair of this committee, he had better pillory the chair of the committee who allowed that, because we would never have heard the end of it if we tried to stop the questions. It is never my wont, as a minister at Senate estimates, to try to stop those sorts of questions but to at least keep them within reasonable bounds.

We spent half the night on that question. We came to the Aussat section of that estimates committee that night—the Senate Hansard will show this—and we did not get a single question from the opposition on the budget variation of $100 million. Mr Goswinkle from Aussat was sitting next to me. He had been waiting for hours and hours to appear before the Senate estimates committee. I told him that I thought we would spend at least two hours on questions about that $100 million budget variation. We did not get a solitary question from the opposition on it. Mr Goswinkle left without having a question put to him, but we spent hours talking about irrelevancies.

The same performance occurred at Senate Estimates Committee E. There was an opportunity to canvass these issues at length and it was not taken up.What did we do? Among other irrelevancies, we spent three hours talking to Mr Hill about why he had criticised the Governor-General of Australia for supporting a continuing monarchy for Australia and not having a republic.

TALK.START.PARA: —How did that relate to the estimates?
—In no way whatsoever. But the chair of the committee allowed the questions.
—And I'm in strife for doing it.
—Now she is in strife for doing so. It is now all Senator West's fault, not the opposition's.
—Who said that?
—Senator Tierney said a few moments ago—Senator Macdonald should read the Hansard—that it is all the fault of the chair of the committee for allowing the questions. That is why I responded as I did.
—And the minister. You were the minister.

—I am glad to be included in that. Senator Tierney should look at the Hansard. I complained about it for three hours. That criticism will not stand, but I am happy to take the interjection. I want it noted, because I look forward to Senator Tierney's support—which I know I will not get—at future Senate estimates committees in keeping the questions to things that are relevant to the estimates. As I have said often, when you do get a question relating to the estimates at Senate estimates committees, it is like a breath of fresh air, because the opposition—and the Hansard record shows it—spends 99 per cent of its time on Senate estimates committees chasing irrelevancies.

PARA.TAB: Who could forget the night I spent on a Senate estimates committee with Senator Bishop, a hearing that went from 8 o'clock one evening to 6 o'clock the following morning without a break and did nothing—

TALK.START.PARA: —Put you through the hoops.

—Ha! It put us through the hoops! It did nothing whatsoever except try to satisfy Senator Bishop's lust for a pint of human blood which she has to have every day. It accomplished nothing. It was about pursuing individuals. It was about pursuing some poor bloke who had worked for SBS but who had left it and is now working for the New South Wales parliamentary Hansard. We spent about five hours canvassing that issue that night.
—How did it relate to the estimates?

—It did not relate to the estimates in any way, shape or form. It had everything to do with Senator Bishop's endless quest for self-promotion and the pursuit of her leader, John Hewson. It had nothing to do with the Senate estimates. That is all Senator Bishop ever uses the Senate estimates for. I am delighted and pleased to say that, in terms of the personal vilification that is visited upon—
—Mr Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. Senator Collins is casting reflections upon one of our colleagues in the Senate. That is not permitted under the standing orders.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Calvert)—I did not hear him say anything personal against her.

TALK.START.PARA: —He is suggesting improper motives.
—Absolutely. I certainly am.
—If you are suggesting improper motives, I ask you to withdraw.

—I withdraw. The Hansard record shows—and I take this opportunity during this debate to canvass this, as I have done so in Senate committees—that 90 per cent of the time spent on estimates committees is literally a waste of time and money. We should have a Senate estimates committee to investigate Senate estimates committees. That is what is required in this parliament, because the way in which they are used in this parliament is a scandal. Ninety-nine per cent of the questions that are pursued on Senate committees on the estimates are never followed up. They are just fishing expeditions that lead nowhere, except to a massive waste of public resources for no good return.
—What's this got to do with the motion?

—I am speaking precisely to the motion. This motion seeks to refer this matter to a Senate estimates committee which has already had an opportunity to examine these matters. It did not do so, but it spent hours talking about issues that have nothing to do with the estimates.

PARA.TAB: A reference has been given to a House of Representatives committee on which I hope the coalition is well represented. There will be a committee in the House to investigate the minister involved. I have no doubt that endless opportunities will present themselves at that committee for all these affairs to be laid out to the public gaze and for a full public account to be given. In terms of the workload and the commitments that we already have in a much overtaxed committee system, as badly as it is used in the Senate, there is absolutely no need to duplicate that process here.

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I will also be brief, as much of the substantive matter was dealt with when we looked at the previous issue. The reason the Australian Democrats supported that first vote is that we believe this matter needs consideration. I reject out of hand what Senator Hill had to say about the Democrats having washed their hands of this matter; that is far from the case.

PARA.TAB: No amount of abuse from Senator Hill or any other coalition senator will get us to change our minds and basically set in train a duplication of what is now being done in the House of Representatives. Let us wait, have a little patience and watch very carefully. When this committee gets under way, we will see whether the documents are available and whether people come before the committee to answer the appropriate questions.

We all understand that we in the Senate have access to all that material as it comes before that committee. Indeed, copies of the Hansard are delivered to our offices. We will be able to keep a very accurate track of what is going on and being said. As has already been stated here, the committee will begin this year. We will be seeing some action. It is not a matter of brushing this under the carpet or anywhere else.

If we are to start discussing the issue here, rather than leaving it to the committee, perhaps I can make one comment. The defence that it was all being done on the basis of need really does not hold up when we look at marginal electorates. It may hold up when looking at safe seats, because they are quite different in their socioeconomic base. We could understand where there would be some possible differences if we were looking at it on the basis of need.

But when we come to seats that, by their very nature, are marginal and where there is a broader cross-section of Australians, some questions have to be asked. Certainly some questions have to be asked about the seats in my state of South Australia. So the Democrats will wait with interest to see what is brought out by the House of Representatives committee.

I remind senators again that the estimates will continue next year. Whatever the minister's feelings about the estimates, we cannot stop them. They will go ahead next year. By the time we get there, we will have even more information on which to base our questions and reopen any questions that need reopening. So, as we approach the busiest time of year for the Senate in terms of the amount of legislation we have to deal with and the number of committee meetings that we all have, let us leave the House of Representatives to do some of the work. We will pick up this issue again once its job is finished.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is most important that we look at the reasons why all this has come about. As Senator Lees has just said, we canvassed the matter prior to the last vote and I do not wish to go over it very much again. Contrary to what the Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Collins) burbled on about, it is particularly significant to look at the way in which the Senate estimates committees have actually got down to the detail of a number of these issues.

PARA.TAB: Why is it that, in a bicameral system, suddenly it is okay for the Democrats to say, `It's all right, let the House of Representatives handle it'? It is absolutely and utterly outrageous to suddenly say, `It is okay to divest ourselves of all responsibility in this matter and put it over to the House of Representatives'. It is quite amazing for the Democrats, who are not represented in the House of Representatives, to be quite happy to abrogate their responsibility to members of a chamber where they are not even represented.

What is it about this whole system? The Democrats surely cannot abrogate their parliamentary responsibility to investigate this issue. They have no right to question the government, they have no right to question the minister, and they have no right to make the government accountable, because they are not members of the committee.

TALK.START.PARA: —What are your colleagues in the House of Representatives going to do—nothing?
—Aren't your House of Representatives colleagues capable of this?
—The dopiest interjections that one could possibly imagine have come from two kooks over on the other side. I was not saying—

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Calvert)—Order! Senator Knowles, I believe the word you used is unparliamentary.

TALK.START.PARA: —Surely `kook' is not unparliamentary, Mr Acting Deputy President?
—There are interjections coming from both sides that I find unparliamentary.
—`Kook' is unparliamentary?
—I believe it may be.
—Did you say `kook'?
—Kook.
—I thought you said `coot'.
—I said `kook'. I will say it in another way. These two absolute goons over here have really just gone beyond the pale in terms of reflecting on my colleagues in the House of Representatives.
—No, you do that.
—Why do you not start listening, Senator Loosley? It will help you hear what is going on.
—Order! Could there be fewer interjections from senators on my right and, Senator Knowles, would you address your remarks through the chair.

—Certainly. I wish that Senator Loosley would listen to what I am saying. Those two intelligent senators opposite—and I ask the Senate to pardon my abuse of their ability—do not understand that the Democrats cannot possibly be represented on a House of Representatives committee because they are not represented in the House of Representatives. I have absolute and utter faith in the members of the coalition parties who are going to be on that committee. We have the ability to be able to question the government in the committee hearing. But that still does not say that we in the Senate should not have the same right to question, through the whole parliamentary system, at an estimates committee. That is exactly what we are seeking.

PARA.TAB: One might ask: how many of these grants that have been made in this typical pork-barrelling by the Labor Party have been made to associations close to the Australian Democrats? That is another question that probably needs to be asked. Why can it not be cleared in an estimates committee hearing? Why do the Australian Democrats want to collude with the government to prevent Estimates Committee E from reconvening to discuss this whole issue in detail? That is all that we are seeking. This has been the most outrageous account of pork-barrelling that we have seen for some time.

TALK.START.PARA: —Even for the Labor Party.

—Even for the Labor Party, as Senator Tierney quite rightly says. More and more examples of this type of misuse of taxpayers' money have come to light following the last election. I have no doubt whatsoever that, over the next 12 months, we will see more and more examples of money having been poured into various interest groups. I have seen it in areas that I am now close to. I have seen the way in which money has been quite judiciously directed into marginal seats and the organisations therein. Yet this Labor Party refuses to produce the documents, refuses to justify what it has done and why it has been done.

PARA.TAB: We all know why it has been done. Let us face it, it was most successful in many areas. Yet a little while ago Minister Schacht asked how we could claim such rot when some of the money went into formerly marginal Labor seats and Labor lost them? Well, well, well. Is that not just hysterical! In other words, Labor did not put enough of the taxpayers' money into those electorates. It is one thing to get public funding for political campaigns and so forth. This is another way in which the Labor Party has been doing it to benefit various interest groups in various portfolios, right across the board.

People in the wider electorate should not for one moment believe that this is an isolated example of where Mrs Kelly has just seen fit to use taxpayers' money immediately prior to an election to try to firm up Labor seats. It is not true. Over the next 12 months we will give further examples of where this money has been pinched out of taxpayers' pockets to go into securing Labor seats. We make no bones about all of that. We seek the Democrats' support to make sure that this Senate chamber has its proper right to have this matter reassessed in the estimates committee hearings.

Prior to the last vote, Senator West said quite erroneously—knowing that what she was saying was wrong, she nonetheless repeated it, not once, not twice, but thrice—that we previously had an opportunity through the Senate estimates hearings to canvass this issue. As Senator West also knows but judiciously failed to mention, even when it was brought to her attention—if she had not been bright enough to know it herself before she got to her feet—this Auditor-General's report which is so critical of Mrs Kelly's performance and that of her office was not even released by the time of the last hearing of Senate Estimates Committee E. Yet Senator West but half an hour ago said that this situation was a disgrace and that this matter should have been raised earlier.

How can people raise something that is in a report if the report has not been tabled? Senator West should apologise to the Senate for the things she has done and said, knowing full well that they are wrong and that she is simply trying to continue the bluff that Minister Kelly has sought to continue in the other chamber, and that subsequent Labor speakers in this chamber have continued. It is not good enough. This matter should go to Senate Estimates Committee E to make sure that the whole detail is fleshed out. If it is not, this whole system that the Labor Party has now developed of pouring taxpayers' money into its seats to continue to prop them up will simply continue.

It is about time taxpayers had a right to know exactly how the government is misusing their money. Look at all the funds that went into the seat of Stirling prior to the last election—Labor's most marginal seat. Yet, budget after budget, portfolio after portfolio, this Labor government poured taxpayers' money into it. Even then, it lost the seat, I am pleased to say. But that did not stop it from pouring in that money.

It is about time the taxpayer had a right to know. It is about time that the issue was fully examined by Estimates Committee E. I encourage Senator Lees and the Democrats to rethink the issue and to make sure that the Senate has an opportunity to look at it. After all, we have a bicameral system.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Loosley Sen S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to oppose the motion before the Senate. I think it is fair to begin by making the observation that former Senator Lionel Murphy was a great political mind and at the end of his political career he was a great jurist on the High Court of Australia. He was an outstanding Australian for whom I had enormous regard and for whom I continue to have enormous regard—more so as I read much of what he wrote in judgments. That regard covers his endeavours as a policy maker, a parliamentarian, a legislator and later on the bench as a jurist.

PARA.TAB: Senator Murphy was the founder of the Senate committee system which we have inherited two political generations beyond his presence in the chamber. Senator Murphy designed an estimates committee system that was almost a perfect vehicle for genuine forensic parliamentarians from both sides of the political fence. I refer in particular to people of the quality of former Senator Walsh and former Senator Peter Baume in those roles.

That said, I believe the late Senator Murphy would spin in his grave if he could witness first hand the abuse of the estimates committee system that we have seen in recent years—the absolute waste and indulgence of a coalition bereft of any ideas. We now see waste, folly and stupidity characterise what the coalition does in this chamber and beyond.

The estimates committee system for some coalition senators has become nothing other than a vehicle for self-glorification. In some respects the government can understand that. It is the only way some people can arrive on the television screens on the evening news. As a Senate we reached a nadir the other night when one coalition senator, who ought to remain nameless because I thought it was a stain upon everyone, said of the Gould prints, `Not bad money for a bit of paint and cardboard'. That was the lowest point possible in political crudity. The silence opposite indicates the agreement.

What happens now when we debate the motion? There is no effective argument for the motion from the coalition. Rarely, if ever, is there an effective argument these days. What the coalition simply does is trash the Democrats. What sort of political approach that actually comes to be I cannot fathom. I cannot fathom why it is that, on every occasion that there is a disagreement between the coalition and the Democrats, the Democrats have be trashed by the Liberal and National parties in such virulent terms.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is what they are.

—Senator Ian Macdonald says, `That is what they are'. I assume that is a reference to virulence. It is politically stupid as well as being unacceptable. Senator Lees and her colleagues can defend themselves and they do not need people in the government doing so. I find that to be absolute stupidity. It is an intolerable abuse of the chamber.

PARA.TAB: For goodness sakes, who on earth is impressed by that kind of behaviour? Who on earth actually registers approval of that kind of behaviour? Certainly not the Australian electorate. Five times now the opposition has been rejected. The opposition is at the point of the end of the Evatt leadership of the ALP and the beginning of the Calwell leadership of the ALP. In terms of an historic framework that is where the opposition is. If the opposition were to sit down and think about it, it would realise that it has the best part of a decade or more to go in opposition. If it continues with this kind of activity and behaviour it will remain in opposition. There is never a glove laid upon us as a government because there is never a serious policy challenge.

All we see is continuing headline hunting. It is an easy and indulgent life in opposition—there is no doubt about that. There is no question that we now face a coalition that is bereft of experience and relevance. If the opposition wants to add bereft of integrity to its list of sins, I do not mind.

Senator West pointed out that Estimates Committee E sat hour after hour. All this material is on the public record. The programs had been criticised by the coalition prior to the estimates committee actually convening. The great forensic parliamentarians opposite—there is no-one of the likes of Peter Baume or Peter Walsh there, that is for sure—have to wait for a report from the Auditor-General to fall into their laps before anything is raised. That shows how easy life in opposition has become. This is an opposition of no consequence. Most of the opposition will grow old over there. The cobwebs are starting to appear.

The coalition has gone from a position where it had a policy statement in vast detail on everything to where it has a policy position on absolutely nothing. So what do we have? We have continuing references to a closed loop in the parliamentary system. They say that things should be referred to the estimates committee, once they have met there should be a supplementary hearing and then the estimates committee should be recalled. We will end with a situation where the estimates committees are sitting 52 weeks of the year.
Mr Oakes's article in the Bulletin makes some remarks which I think are pointed. He states:
The senate committee system is great in theory, a powerful means of keeping the executive properly accountable to parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not disagree with that. He continues:
In practice it is hugely wasteful.
There is no question about that either. He goes on to say later in the article:

PARA.TAB: It is certainly fascinating to watch the rudeness that some notable senate figures use as a substitute for forensic skill in estimates committee hearings. But that $8 million price tag makes it a very expensive spectator sport.

SPEECH.PARA: There is no doubt about that. That brings us back to the point that Senator West was making. All the material was on the public record.

TALK.START.PARA: —It's a blood sport.

—It has become a blood sport mainly at the expense of people in the Public Service who cannot answer for themselves. Those opposite should ask themselves why the Public Service vote has shifted during the decade of the 1980s. Why has it shifted away from the opposition so demonstrably? Why is it that those opposite cannot possibly win either of the ACT seats. Those opposite will not win the third seat when it is created.

PARA.TAB: Consistently those opposite have alienated the Public Service by abuse at those estimates committee. Keep going; there are no votes in it for them. I can guarantee it. Keep going; there are no votes in this kind of nonsense either. This closed loop that those opposite have created is only for themselves. It is its own form of entertainment. Those opposite do not need pay TV; they watch themselves in estimates committees. This is the closed loop of Australian parliamentary performance. No other chamber in the world would indulge in this kind of arrant nonsense in which those opposite routinely indulge themselves.

I think Senator Lees or Senator Collins made the point earlier that we do have a bicameral system. It is appropriate from time to time that the House of Representatives actually take on a little more of the parliamentary workload. The estimates committees give the government a majority. The House of Representatives committee presumably will have a government majority, but otherwise all the procedures are virtually identical. The skills are the same in both houses presumably and given the workload of the Senate between now and Christmas it is entirely appropriate that the House do a bit more work. No-one is suggesting for one moment that people on the House of Representatives committee are not capable of asking the questions or of actually conducting the exercise. No-one has suggested that.

The motion leads us nowhere. It leads us back into the closed loop—back into the closed circuit. We have seen the performance of some coalition senators on estimates filibustering and that sort of nonsense; they have been going around the clock. Dozens of highly paid public servants are kept there into the small hours of the morning. The staff of Parliament House are kept here until the small hours of the morning. This is absolute nonsense.

TALK.START.PARA: —The public servants are brought in from all parts of Australia too.

—They are brought in from all parts of the Commonwealth to service the egos of those opposite. In Mrs Kelly's program there were more Labor seats, the marginal seats had greater need and Labor MPs lobbied more effectively. When one looks at Ron Edwards there is no doubting the truth of that statement. Also some of our constituencies have particular and special needs. This is particularly so of some of the ethnic communities and some of the black communities. There is no question about that.

PARA.TAB: Senator Hill says that the opposition will need only a day. He said that; I did not. Do those opposite know how many grants are involved? There are 700. Are those opposite going to review the 700 grants in a day? Are they going to review all the letters that Mrs Kelly has on file thanking her? One that I have comes from the Leeton Shire, which is in a tory seat. Is that correct, Senator West?

TALK.START.PARA: —My word.
—It is not one of ours. The letter states:

SPEECH.PARA: We are delighted with the announcement . . . of an offer of a $100,000 grant to the Council to assist with construction of the facility, which will provide a much needed asset in our community for many years to come.

There are a host of letters like that from conservative seats. Which ones are those opposite going to look at? They would have to look at the 700. Are they going to do that in a day? For goodness sakes, no-one believes that. That will roll on for a week. They are well aware of that. This is easily a week's headline hunting.

PARA.TAB: The other night we reached the absolute bottom of the agenda—a lot of money for a bit of paint and cardboard. My God! Leaving aside the fact that that was a remark of a philistine, it was simply a remark that stained the Senate chamber. This motion ought to be defeated for all the reasons I have given. It is a duplication, it is a waste, it is an indulgence and it simply furthers the egos of some people who think the Senate estimates committee process, as Senator West said earlier, is an exercise in blood sport.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tierney Sen J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the motion moved by Senator Hill and urge Senator Lees and her fellow Democrats to support it also, if for no other reason than the fact that they will not have the opportunity to ask any questions in a House of Representatives inquiry. If we followed that argument through to its logical conclusion, we would not have any Senate committees at all. Senate committees are there because of their strength and ability to cross-examine and require governments to be called to account.

PARA.TAB: In terms of being called to account, I find the debate to date absolutely amazing. Speakers from the other side, with the exception of Senator Loosley in his last three or four minutes, did not address any of the substantive issues at all. We had a great diatribe from Senator Collins, who wasted our time for 20 minutes talking about wasting time on estimates committees, yet I well remember back in May sitting through an estimates committee hearing until 2 o'clock in the morning in which Senator Collins would not allow any of his public servants to answer questions on pay TV. He took every question himself and then refused to answer the questions. He talks about wasting time. He has wasted so much time of this chamber—not only in estimates but in here—that a special Hansard was produced of everything Senator Collins had said on pay TV, which filled about two volumes. I think it is Senator Collins who wastes time, not anyone else.
Senator West deliberately misled us by claiming that in Estimates Committee E earlier this month we had the opportunity—
The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Calvert)—Order! Senator Tierney, I do not think you are within the standing orders to accuse another senator of deliberately misleading the house.

TALK.START.PARA: —If I provide the evidence, it is in the information before me.

—I withdraw, Mr Acting Deputy President. Senator West tried to indicate that we had all this evidence before us and asked why we did not bring it out in the committee hearings. One would wonder—perhaps Senator West has an answer to this—why this Auditor-General's report happened to be tabled on 15 November, after the estimates procedures had finished. I have looked into this matter on a number of occasions with other departments and I found that they could have tabled things months before they did. PARA.TAB: I urge the Democrats to allow us the opportunity—which the government has denied us by releasing this report so late—to go through the Auditor-General's report, as we do in many estimates hearings, and question the government in detail on the findings. We would have been able to do that if we had this report in our hands on 5 November.

TALK.START.PARA: —Aren't you intelligent enough to use this document?

—It is probably a one-line item in the program performance statements. And how much detail is provided on this $29 million? Not much at all. The detail is in the Auditor-General's report, which has outlined in great detail what this government has done with its disgraceful waste of public money in terms of pork-barrelling. If it is such a great idea to spend money in this way, one would wonder why the government is not continuing to spend it that way this year. Why has it disappeared out of this program if it was such a good idea?
—It was an election year.
—I wonder whether it was because this year was an election year, as Senator O'Chee has indicated. Perhaps Senator O'Chee might predict when the next lot of pork-barrelling will take place.
—Two years.

—Yes, in 1995 we will see a similar exercise with the government pork-barrelling disgracefully across marginal electorates. Labor received 73 per cent of the grants. The average Labor seat received $257,000 compared with $147,000 received by coalition seats. Marginal Labor seats received exactly double the amount that coalition seats did. We call on the Australian Democrats to support us in the investigation of this disgraceful waste of public money. If the Democrats need any convincing, they should read this Auditor-General's report.

PARA.TAB: In relation to the $29 1/2 million program, the Auditor-General:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . noted some anomalies in the approval of grants . . . by the Minister but was unable to resolve them because the reasons for the decisions were not adequately documented.

I thought it was a requirement of all government departments, particularly when they were distributing 700 grants to particular communities, to document that. Why has it not been documented? It is probably for the same reason that all government speakers in this debate have not addressed any of these issues at all. They have run from the real debate, and for good reason. The report also says:
ANAO considers that it is in the interests of a Minister to document the reasons for individual decisions to allay such allegation and to provide accountability for decisions.
Why was the accountability not provided? It is fairly obvious that it was deliberate pork-barrelling. The most damming comment is:
The role of the minister's staff in the selection of grants appears significant.

Anyone who has watched Yes, Minister on many occasions should be able to interpret what is meant by that. The minister's office was directing the grants to the seats where it felt it would do the most electoral good.

PARA.TAB: The Labor Party says that it does not believe in the level playing field. It certainly does not believe in the level field when it comes to elections; it tilts it by telling lies, it tilts it by rorting the electoral system and it tilts it by pork-barrelling the electorate to make sure it wins the seats.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: West Sen S.M.

To say that Senate Estimates Committee E has not been sitting for considerable lengths of time would be a slightly erroneous statement! We have taken up exactly 593 pages of Hansard.
