PARA.TAB: Program 4 of the program performance statements of 1993-94 of the environment, sport and territories portfolio relates to sport and recreation. Subprogram 4.1 relates to policy and program support. Then—surprise, surprise—we have subprogram 4.2, facilities. It says:

SPEECH.PARA: Through the Community Cultural, Recreation and Sporting Facilities program . . . the Government promotes the development of community level sport . . .
It has a whole subprogram to itself. Subprogram 4.3 relates to the Australian Sports Commission and subprogram 4.4 concerns the Australian Sports Drug Agency.

PARA.TAB: If I turn to the appropriate Hansard of 21 September, when we dealt with this department, I find that it starts from program 3, meteorology—there is a bit over a page of questioning there—and goes to program 5. There was not one question from those opposite on the whole of the sports and recreation area. Yet there was a subprogram for this particular issue that they are complaining about. How could they say that they could not ask questions because the ANAO report had not been brought down? It was in the program performance statements, but they were not able to look at that document to see whether there might have been something that drew their attention to it.

In the other place and in here prior to estimates those opposite have said, `This is a terrible program'. But when they had the opportunity—unfettered—to go through this program piece by piece, to ask whether it was delivering the outcomes that they thought it should be delivering, what were the outcomes, why were there changes in the amounts of money, these sorts of things, there was not one question. Mr Acting Deputy President, I recall that you might have been there. Certainly some of your colleagues were there and, as I say, did not ask one question.

When it came to supplementary estimates time—I am going from memory here—I do not recall anything on sport except in relation to the sports drug agency. Again, there was not one question. Nobody came. Nobody appeared to be interested. They could not be bothered doing their own work. They have to get other people to do it. Once somebody else has done the forensic work for them they think that they might have time for, as Verona Burgess from the Canberra Times says, `indulging in a discursive and apparently quite pointless rehearsal of their own opinions'.

That is what they want to do; that is what their plan is. But they can do nothing constructive. They have had several opportunities. As I say, this estimates committee has met on a number of occasions. I have never attempted to stifle debate in it because I am in strife in the media for not doing that. We have the media saying, quite rightly so, that this is a waste of time.

Those opposite come in here and claim that they need to now take the matter to estimates because they could not look at this subprogram and do their own investigative work. Senator Ferguson did do his work—did it very well—in estimates, but nobody else from the opposition did. He was left there at one stage for five hours to do the questioning and nobody came near him. Some people had other committee commitments. However, when our schedule of sittings came out in July and August of this year, for the weeks starting 1 November and 8 November, we were told that it was time that was available for supplementary estimates hearings. Yet other people chose to go off with other committees elsewhere. That is a decision that they have to make, but they do not need to come back in here at a later date and say that they want to reopen something because they chose to do something different.

TALK.START.PARA: —You should not have set committee hearings during those times. You had the majority on those committees. Why did you set them during those times?

—The numbers were never used. You were all advised as soon as we were looking at particular dates, and they had to fit in with the ministers. I suppose you think that we should haul them in and make ministers break their appointments. We do have this matter being investigated by the House of Representatives. What honourable senators choose to forget is that these grants were allocated on an electorate by electorate basis. Maybe it is important that those people who have electorates are actually the ones who look at how it is distributed—not us, who have statewide boundaries and who can afford to sit back and pontificate, gaze at our navels and think of all sorts of nice woolly wonderful things. But maybe it is appropriate that those who are actually involved, those who have to answer to the grassroots and to their electorates, are the ones who do it.

PARA.TAB: The opposition chooses to ride roughshod over them. It has shown absolute disdain for the lower house, for the people who are elected by this country to form the government. The opposition seems to think that the superior place is the upper house and, from the reaction of the opposition to being defeated in March of this year, it would appear that it certainly would like to be like the House of Lords and never have to face an election. Those opposite cannot take the defeat that the people of this country handed out to them.

So let us reiterate. Program 4.2 was the program that the opposition chose to ask no questions about, and it had plenty of time. It further had supplementary estimates, when it chose again to ask no questions. Yet it now wants to come in here and say, `Please, somebody has come up with a report we do not like. Those opposite did not have the wit or the will or the wisdom—or the ability perhaps—to actually look at this subprogram and say, `Maybe I can ask a question on that'. But they say, `Somebody has come up with a report. Please let me have a go.' How much more of its thinking does the opposition have to get people to do for it?

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I take a point of order. We are all amused by Senator West's various impersonations but I would ask you to direct her to direct her comments through the chair.

—I rule that there is no point of order and remind Senator O'Chee that a certain degree of tolerance is given in this chamber which has been established previously and which I am following through. However, I will take note of the point of order raised by Senator O'Chee and ask all honourable senators to refrain from interjections to allow the senator to address the chair.
—Mr Acting Deputy President, I apologise for not passing my questions and my comments through you. I close by quoting Laurie Oakes:

SPEECH.PARA: Grilling public servants in senate estimates committee hearings and alleging waste, mismanagement and incompetence. Suggesting cover-ups and conspiracies—and making heroes of themselves. And what have they uncovered? Not much at all.

I think that sums up this whole situation. Opposition members have uncovered nothing because they did not ask any questions. They did not have the will or the wit to do so. Now that somebody else has asked some questions they think they should be able to follow on and just ramble along, as Verona Burgess said, `in a pointless, discursive and apparently pointless rehearsal of their own opinions'.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macdonald Sen I.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I enjoyed that speech from Senator West. It was quite humorous and entertaining. It said nothing factual, except that Senator West did draw attention to the fact that the media had, I thought somewhat unkindly, criticised her for her chairmanship. She rather unkindly did not go on to say that the media was rather kind about the extent of my questioning. I would have hoped that Senator West might have been generous enough to mention that.

PARA.TAB: This matter that we are discussing—and one would not understand it from what Senator West has just said—is a very serious matter about the Labor Party dealing with government funds as if they were its own. To recapitulate, I remind the Senate that the Auditor-General's report, which came out—for Senator West's information, if she does not remember—several days after the Senate estimates committee hearings had concluded, indicates that 73 per cent of the number of grants and 66 per cent of the value of the grants went to Labor seats. The amount of money per Labor seat was $257,000, whereas for a coalition seat it was $141,000, clearly showing that these grants—which are allocated by the minister herself and not by the department, not by any committee—had a clear preference for the Labor seats.
Senator Burns interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —That should not surprise Senator Burns and it does not surprise me. The same sort of thing happened with the local capital works project. I repeat the figures that the then minister, Mr Simmons, released to the House of Representatives on 19 September 1992 in relation to

SPEECH.PARA: the local capital works projects—66 per cent of those handouts just before the election went to Labor seats and only 72 per cent of those grants went to coalition seats. So here it is yet again in a different field. We are talking about grants for sports and cultural organisations. I am talking about the local capital works projects that went to councils just before the election. Again, that magic figure, 66 per cent of grants went to Labor held seats and 32 per cent went to coalition seats. It is interesting to do the figures on the table that Mr Simmons tabled in the parliament. The amount of local capital works projects that went to Labor electorates was $6,227,000-odd. For coalition electorates it was $3,364,000.

PARA.TAB: Just to be accurate, I suppose I should say that the amount that went to the Independent seats—they did not go to the two Independent electorates; they only went to one of them, that of Wills, which the Labor Party was hoping to win back from the Independent—lo and behold, was $14.6 million. There we are—$14.6 million for the seat the Labor Party had to win back; $6.2 million on average for every Labor Party electorate, and $3.3 million on average for every coalition electorate.

The Labor Party has to be made to understand that this is taxpayers' money; it belongs to the people of Australia, and it cannot be used by the Labor Party for crass political purposes in buying votes before an election. That is why it is important that this matter go to the Senate estimates committee for further investigation. It is essential.

I cannot understand why the Democrats are opposing this matter. The party which was formed to keep the bastards honest allows this sort of dishonesty by a government to continue. One could almost wonder whether the Democrats have something to fear. Perhaps the Democrats are concerned that if we open up the estimates committee hearing into the Department of the Environment, Sport and Territories, we might start looking more closely at what sort of grants went to conservation groups which are aligned to them. Maybe the Democrats do not want those sorts of things investigated. Maybe there has been a deal between the government and the Democrats on who gets the money that is shovelled out. It may be for this reason that the Democrats are opposing it.

We do know that the Australian Democrats is a party of hypocrisy. Mr Acting Deputy President, you might recall that the Democrats as a party was always solid in its support of the United Nations, except when it came to Kuwait. It again showed its hypocrisy by one year arguing very viciously against the forced creation of mega-unions and the next year arguing equally vociferously in favour of it. The Democrats is a party of hypocrisy in claiming to support the transport industry and then voting against the abolition of sales tax and fuel tax, and supporting increases in sales tax and fuel excise which added millions to the costs of the transport industry.

The Australian Democrats showed their hypocrisy by pretending to be the party of human rights and then siding with the Labor Party to ban electoral advertising—to ban free speech—in this country. They showed hypocrisy by calling for environmentally friendly power supplies and then opposing the cleanest form of power around—hydro-electric power. That sort of hypocrisy is what the Australian Democrats have become known for. It is no wonder that the Democrats, which again have a chance to support us in keeping the government honest, have chosen to continue their line of hypocrisy by opposing this opportunity for scrutiny.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will speak very briefly on this matter, which is all about whether we should recall Senate Estimates Committee E. It seems as though the government has a different standard on the question of recalling estimates committees—it is a matter of whether the government wants to recall an estimates committee or whether we want to recall it.

PARA.TAB: I am pleased that Senator West is in the chamber because she will no doubt remember that only a couple of months ago a minister wished to recall an estimates committee—as a matter of fact, Estimates Committee E—because he became aware of some more information which he wanted the estimates committee to hear. As minister, he saw absolutely nothing improper about recalling an estimates committee—the very thing we are debating this afternoon—because he became aware of some more information.

It just so happens that the opposition has decided that it wants to recall Estimates Committee E because it has become aware of some more information. If it is good enough for the government to recall an estimates committee because it has more information, I do not see why it should not be equally as appropriate for the opposition to recall an estimates committee because it has become aware of some more information. No doubt, Senator Schacht will remember that well, because he was the minister who recalled Estimates Committee E in order to provide information.

This is a case where the information was neither readily available nor easily discernible. I cannot understand why the Australian Democrats, who did not see anything wrong with the government recalling an estimates committee to provide more information to us, will not support us in this situation now that we have become aware of more information, and certainly more revealing information.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why do you want to recall it? It was in estimates before.

—The whole point is that the Democrats are the ones who say that they want to be a part of this process because they are the ones who are keeping the government honest. There are no Democrats in the House of Representatives. If the Democrats want to be a part of the process of determining whether what was done was correct and proper, the only way this can be achieved is by this chamber recalling the estimates committee.

PARA.TAB: I think the scrutiny of public expenditure has sometimes been hindered. Senator Schacht, who appeared before us in Estimates Committee E, agreed that the lack of information in program performance statements sometimes leads to an inability, certainly on the part of public servants, to provide answers on the spot. Many of the program performance statements contain only one line. We ask questions; and public servants are required to give the answers. But they do not have the information because not enough information is put into the program performance statements. We are unable to scrutinise properly the spending. Certainly, in many cases they are unable to answer the questions that we put before them.

Senator West, or it might have been Senator Collins, made a comment about public servants coming from all over Australia. I think both Senator West and Senator Collins ought to acknowledge that we made every effort, particularly during the supplementary estimates hearings, to accommodate on the agenda those public servants who were travelling long distances. On almost every occasion they were able to leave early or we were able to make sure that we finished their program so that they would not be an added cost to the country by being kept here overnight. It would not hurt the government to acknowledge the fact that we made particular reference to this at estimates hearings. We made sure that, wherever possible, public servants were not kept waiting for their program to come up.

Minister Kelly may have said in the other house that she would deal with this matter as expeditiously as possible. But the only place where this can be dealt with properly, where the Democrats can have an input if they wish and where the whole of the expenditure can be reviewed, would be before Estimates Committee E. Estimates Committee E should be recalled in just the same way that Senator Schacht recalled the estimates committee when he had further information that he wanted to put before it.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not want to speak for long, other than to endorse fully the remarks of my colleague Senator Ferguson. I simply would draw attention to some of the remarks that Senator `Did-you-send-me-a-cheque' Loosley chose to make. That is what he should be known as: Senator `Did-you-send-me-a-cheque' Loosley. In fact, that is what he used to be known as.
—Mr Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. Senator Vanstone is transgressing standing orders by reflecting on the reputation of another senator and her remarks should be withdrawn.

—Mr Acting Deputy President, if I can be of assistance to you on the point of order: I think what I said is that is what he used to be known as, and he certainly used to be known as that. I do not allege that he is known as it now; I just query whether perhaps he ought to be. But if that remark is offensive, if people seem to know immediately that it has some negative interpretation and they attach it to something negative, I will withdraw. Heavens above!

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator McKiernan)—Senator Vanstone, I ask you to withdraw.

TALK.START.PARA: —I withdraw. Senator Loosley chose to make some remarks about something I had said in an estimates committee hearing. He tried to grace himself with glory by saying that he would not name the senator who said it, but that it was a disgraceful remark. I am happy to nominate myself as being the senator who said, `A lot of money for a bit of paint and cardboard'. On this occasion, the difference is, with Senator Loosley not having his facts right—as has been the case with him on numerous other occasions—that he either knows the facts are wrong or has not bothered to find out.

PARA.TAB: When I approached Senator Loosley to try to save some time—because I know honourable senators do not want to go on for a long time about this matter—and said, `You'd know that is untrue if you'd bothered to check the Hansard', he threw up his hands and said, `Well, look, the perception is that that's what you said about the Gould prints, so that's the perception'. He did not come in here and say, `The perception is that a senator said that a lot of money had been paid for the Gould prints and that they were a bit of paint on a bit of cardboard'. He actually said that that is what a senator said. So, for Senator Loosley's benefit and that of others, I make the point that I was on the estimates committee that was looking into the purchase of the Gould prints for the cabinet room, on the instructional preference of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating). I asked a question with respect to the framing and mounting of those.

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh, come on.

—`Oh, come on', says Senator Bolkus. I have had it with those opposite being misleading, twisting things and getting away with what they like. I simply want to take a couple of minutes to point out a suitable remedy which is available to me and which I am going to use—because I have had enough. This has come from Senator Loosley and from other people here who deliberately twist statements in order to cause trouble. I do not mind the rough and tumble of debate, a good bit of abuse across the chamber about each other's policies. If some of those on the other side want to make personal remarks, that is one thing. But to deliberately mislead the chamber about what a senator has said is another. That is simply totally unacceptable.
—So what do you reckon you said?

—What I said was that to pay over $3,000 for 17 bits of cardboard, which is the mounting that goes around the Gould prints—and, as I used to have a business that sold framing, I have a very good understanding about what a French line and wash mount is, and it is not worth $200-and-whatever it is when we divide $3,000-something by 17—was simply not worth that much money. A mount is a piece of coloured cardboard; if it has a French line and wash on it, it has a bit of paint on it. The remark I made was that it was not worth that much money.

PARA.TAB: I realise that one of Senator Loosley's senior colleagues in the other place has sought to have the same bit of fun, saying that the coalition is a load of crass something-or-others who would regard Gould prints as a bit of paint on cardboard. Members of the government seek to make that misrepresentation and they can continue to do so. They will pay a price, and the price will be evident.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not need to make the obvious point that I will be speaking but ever so briefly, but I am provoked to rise because I heard the latter part of the remarks of Senator West, who was Chairman of Estimates Committee E. She drew in an unhappy way, in my view, the observation that there were members of the opposition not present at Estimates Committee E during the deliberations of the supplementary estimates. She further noted that there were very few questions on the matter of sport and, for reasons of which I am not certain, referred to questions on drugs in sport.

PARA.TAB: I am a member of Estimates Committee E. I asked on two occasions—perhaps selfishly, but in a sense of goodwill—for the date and the time of the hearing to be at a time which would accommodate the problem I had in attending. I was unable to be at the estimates because I was at the European Parliament on the first occasion and I was overseas again, but ever so briefly, on the second occasion. On both occasions I asked whether the hearing dates could be changed. I do not think it was a problem for anybody on our side of politics, but it was a problem for the minister. I think he was wanting to go overseas himself or wanting to undertake some other duties. So, to that extent, the committee's dates, as I recall at least, were to accommodate the minister.

The history of the Liberal Party in respect of asking questions in estimates committees on sport, as with the standing committee, is unparalleled. We have spent very many hours on our side of politics asking questions in respect of that matter. I have to say, in not an ingenuous way, that I do not recall an occasion, save for one, where any member of the government has ever asked any questions at Estimates Committee E about sport or drugs in sport. But I would have thought the fact that I was unable to be there for reasons quite beyond my control was not a good reason for Senator West to seek to make an unfortunate point today.
Question put:
That the motion (Senator Hill's) be agreed to:
Question so resolved in the negative.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Consideration of House of Representatives Message

PARA.TAB: Message received from the House of Representatives acquainting the Senate that the House of Representatives had disagreed to the amendment made by the Senate, and desired the reconsideration by the Senate of the bill in respect of the said amendment.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Schedule of the amendment made by the Senate to which the House of Representatives has disagreed—
Clause 16, page 7, at the end add the following subsections:
"(2) Reasonable steps to help the complainant include supplying the complainant with written information about, and method of contacting, any organisation that is:

TAB.TAB: (a)engaged in providing consumers with advice or assistance or both on (but not necessarily exclusively on) superannuation, including the making of complaints and the resolution of disputes; and
(b)independent of the Tribunal and any fund; and
(c)supported, in whole or part, by funds appropriated for that purpose; and
(d)prescribed by regulations as an independent superannuation advisory service for the purposes of this section; and
(e)reasonably accessible to the complainant.".

PROCTEXT.PARA: "(3) If regulations referred to in paragraph (2)(d):

TAB.TAB: (a)are not in force immediately after the commencement of this Act; or
(b)have been disallowed;

PARA.TAB: the Minister must table in each House of the Parliament, not later than 5 sitting days of that House after:

PROCTEXT.PARA: (c)commencement of this Act; or

TAB.TAB: (d)such disallowance;

PROCTEXT.PARA: a statement explaining why the intention of the Parliament expressed in that paragraph:

TAB.TAB: (e)has not been complied with; or
(f)has been complied with inadequately.

PROCTEXT.PARA: "(4) Subsection (2) and (3) are repealed 3 years after the day of commencement of this Act.
Reasons of the House of Representatives for disagreeing to the amendment of the Senate—
1.The Superannuation (Resolution of Complaints) Bill 1993 makes provision for complainants to be assisted by the Tribunal in making complaints.
Under the Bill the tribunal is obliged to:
assist a person in making a complaint (clause 16); and

make arrangements so that information about how complaints may be lodged and how they will be resolved are made reasonably available to members of regulated superannuation funds and beneficiaries of approved deposit funds (clause 13);

These services will be provided by the Tribunal through a full-time secretariat based in Sydney, which will be able to be contacted from anywhere in Australia through a toll free (008) telephone number. Offices of the Insurance and Superannuation Commission in State capital cities will also be able to assist and refer complainants to the secretariat.
The Tribunal will be in the best position to assist complainants, assess a complainants problem and to determine whether or not the Tribunal can hear the complaint.

The Tribunal and its secretariat can be relied upon to provide accurate and impartial assistance in resolving complaints. The secretariat who will, in practice provide the assistance to complainants will be staffed by public servants who have no vested interest in the outcome.

Given that the Bill addresses the concerns raised by the consumer movement in proposing the service, it is highly questionable whether the $660,000 needed for its establishment is an appropriate use of public revenue.

2.Should the Government endorse mandatory referral of complainants to a Service of the kind proposed, there would be pressure for lawyers from the service to represent the complainants before the Tribunal.
This would undermine the objectives of the Tribunal as a low cost, informal and expeditious disputes resolution mechanism.

PARA.TAB: Ordered that consideration of the message in committee of the whole proceed forthwith.
Motion (by Senator Sherry) proposed:
That the committee does not insist upon the amendment made by the Senate to which the House of Representatives has disagreed.

TALK.START.PARA: —The amendment had the support of the Liberal-National party coalition. Since that time, the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer (Mr Johns) plus officers from the ISC have consulted with the opposition and other interested parties.

PARA.TAB: When the report of the Senate Select Committee on Superannuation goes back to the President, we will be moving an amendment to the effect that the matter be referred to the committee for inquiry and report on the first sitting day in October 1995. That report will be about the operation of the Superannuation Complaints Tribunal for its first 12 months, whether the tribunal was adequately meeting the needs of the superannuation fund members, and whether an independent superannuation consumer advice service should be established and supported by grants from consolidated revenue.

It appeared to be a not unreasonable request from the parliamentary secretary, Mr Johns, that this innovation—the tribunal which was set up and designed to meet consumer interests—be given a reasonable chance of operation. So, in a sense, during the tribunal's first 12 months the superannuation committee will be monitoring its operation as to the manner in which it assists consumers in their difficulties in relation to superannuation. We believe that this is a not unreasonable approach under the circumstances because the tribunal will be very conscious that a parliamentary committee, in the form of the Select Committee on Superannuation, will be monitoring its actions, at the end of 12 months will be conducting an inquiry, and by the first sitting day in October 1995 will be reporting back to the Senate in the terms of the three issues that I have put before the Senate.

I turn to the issues that were of concern to the members of the select committee when they made a recommendation that perhaps there was a need for a consumer legal service. I think we have to acknowledge that some of the members who advocated that have since moved into other positions. There will be a monitoring and an oversight of the need for a consumer representative service in this area. Therefore, I will be moving an amendment when we are considering that the report of the committee be adopted. I thank the Senate and I thank all the officers who were involved in this exchange.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was with some reluctance that I considered the Australian Democrats' position on this matter. I would like to ask the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Senator Sherry), who is at the table, how we are going to maintain the independence and the right to representation of consumers. Sure, the Superannuation Complaints Tribunal is going to do its best, and it will have 18 people, but it is under the umbrella of the ISC, which is the government's Insurance and Superannuation Commission. How will we ensure that consumers can be dealt with fairly? How is the tribunal going to balance its responsibilities to both the government and the consumers at the same time?

PARA.TAB: I am disappointed that the government wishes to bring this amendment back to this chamber. I just do not accept that consumers will be best served by a rejection of our amendment. It is true that the Senate Select Committee on Superannuation recommended the legal centre's approach as a cost-effective alternative to expanding the rights of representation. We are being asked to monitor the tribunal for a year. I accept Senator Watson's argument that it is better for the Senate select committee to monitor the tribunal for a year. My problem is: at the end of that year, how do we get the government to do anything about it? It is a fine notion to say, `Let's monitor it for a year'.

TALK.START.PARA: —We can't get them to do it.
—We can get the government to do things; it is the coalition which is now changing its mind on this, which I think is very disappointing.
—There is another house.
—There is another house, and I cannot understand why Senator Watson's colleagues in the other house were not able to support his actions on this legislation. But that is another issue.

PARA.TAB: We cannot deny the fact that we are talking about $169 billion in funds, we are talking about 70 per cent of Australian workers, and we are saying that the government is not prepared to look at something like $660,000 in the short term, because we were prepared to put a sunset clause in here and say that this gives time for government and industry to work together. It is a very weak compromise and I am disappointed that the coalition has had to review its position on this amendment. I am waiting to hear Senator Sherry's answer as to how the tribunal, even with the best will in the world, can fairly represent both government and consumer.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —Firstly, in relation to the issue of the tribunal representing government fairly, with due respect to Senator Kernot I think she misunderstands the relationship between the tribunal and the government. The tribunal will be set up in the same way that the Industrial Relations Commission was established. It will be an arms-length institution. I think the independence of the Industrial Relations Commission is well known—
—Is it?

—It is well known. It is notoriously well known according to the secretary of the ACTU. It is envisaged that, in some respects, the tribunal will operate in a similar manner. It will adjudicate fairly and independently; it will be a statutory organisation; and I do not believe that the connection Senator Kernot envisages between government and tribunal will exist. It is an independent statutory organisation.
—What about government and ISC?

—Or from the ISC. From a reading of the legislation, I do not believe there is the sort of relationship that Senator Kernot envisages. I certainly am confident that the tribunal will operate in the way that is envisaged.

PARA.TAB: On the second point Senator Kernot raised, the government has committed itself to looking at the recommendations of the Senate Select Committee on Superannuation. It sounds as though Senator Kernot is a little sceptical about the way in which the government will look at it. I am not sceptical—

TALK.START.PARA: —It will look at it. Will it spend any money? That's the issue.

—I believe the government will evaluate it properly and fairly and see whether there are obvious weaknesses for consumers. But even if the legal service was funded to the extent that Senator Kernot would wish, frankly, that will be a very small amount of funding compared to what I believe will be the consumer demand in the sense of the demand on the tribunal.
—So deny them the lot. It is much easier to deny them.

—No, that is not correct. Senator Kernot is following the argument through to an illogical conclusion. I suggest that there will be other mechanisms. I have always been confident that a range of advocates will emerge, whether they be trade union officials or independent advocates—hopefully not too many of them who will charge what lawyers charge—because lawyers are prevented from appearing before the tribunal.

PARA.TAB: I think it is important to ascertain the extent of the service and the consumer demand on the service—as I say, I have always believed it would be considerable—before we set about, in a premeditated way, funding an organisation that may not be necessary. For those reasons, the government has maintained its stance. We are appreciative that Senator Watson understands that and obviously we will be supporting the amendment that will be moved by Senator Watson.

TALK.START.PARA: —Does the parliamentary secretary accept that there is a feeling abroad that the ISC leans more towards representing the funds than it does consumers at this stage? Secondly, the Australian Federation of Consumer Organisations is having a phone-in tomorrow, which Senator Sherry might be aware of, and I was just wondering whether he would be willing to assess the evidence from that phone-in. If we were even able to defer this bill for just one more day, we might have been able to get an indication of the types of concerns that superannuation consumers actually have. It seems that we are determined to press on with this tonight, so I would like some commitment from Senator Sherry that the government will, in fact, consider AFCO's logs of the complaints that will come in as part of this phone-in.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —In respect of the second issue first, I am confident that there will be thousands of calls and I hope there are—not that I hope thousands of people have had wrong done by them in the superannuation industry, but I am confident that there are many people with legitimate concerns about superannuation. I believe there will be many phone calls for that reason, just as there have been many hundreds of complaints before the committee that Senator Kernot is well aware of.

PARA.TAB: The next step in her argument is that if we wait for the phone-in and there are thousands of complaints—let us assume that happens—we then need an independent legal advisory service shortly thereafter. I do not accept the flow of that logic.

TALK.START.PARA: —If there are thousands, how is a secretariat of 18 going to deal with it?

—Let us see how it copes with it. But establishing the legal centres does not overcome that problem, if there is going to be a problem, for the tribunal. I suspect there will be a heavy initial workload on the tribunal. I believe that would be the case for two reasons. I think there will be an initial rush, if you like, of people who have been aggrieved over, say, the last year or two and over the next nine months prior to the tribunal's commencing.

PARA.TAB: I think many companies, once they know the tribunal is coming into operation, will modify their practice—at the moment some are responsive to consumer concerns but some are not—and I think that will minimise a lot of the consumer complaints. But initially there will be significant consumer complaint. I still do not believe that that phone-in tomorrow, even if it shows up significant numbers of concerns, will necessarily translate into huge pressure on the tribunal and I do not accept that we set up the legal service prior to the operation of the tribunal.

As for the first point that the ISC leans towards the funds, I do not agree with that. If Senator Kernot means it leans towards the funds in the sense that it is tolerant of mistakes that are made by the trustees of funds often in ignorance, I believe that to be the case. For the trustees, for example, to change the rules of the fund—having been a trustee myself—is not an easy thing to do. There have been many changes to the law that were applied retrospectively, so I think the ISC is tolerant of those sorts of problems that a fund encounters. It is tolerant of that also because it is dealing with, in a sense, lay trustees and it has not been easy during this transition period of improved regulation over the last years for fund trustees in some cases to cope with that change in legislation.

I do not accept that the ISC leans towards the funds in the sense that it is tolerant of trustees not taking into account the legitimate concerns of the members of the funds. I do not believe that happens. The difficulty at the moment is that the ISC does not have the sorts of powers that it should have to deal with member complaint. At the moment we have a voluntary code of practice where the companies are supposed to—and I think in a significant number of cases do—respond to complaints of members of the funds.

In order to get around that problem, we are establishing a tribunal. One of the reasons the tribunal is being established is that I do not believe the ISC has been able to deal with those consumer complaints in a ready and effective way. I accept that the ISC leans towards the funds—for different reasons from those Senator Kernot has advanced—in the consumer area.

Finally, Senator Murphy has just reminded me that many of the funds over the last year or two have established the practice of setting up their own independent offices within the fund. So there is another mechanism. That will be required under this legislation, but many of the funds have been establishing independent offices to handle the sorts of concerns that members have if the trustees do not respond to their complaints in a satisfactory manner.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Senator Sherry) said that the tribunal is at arms length from the government; that is true. But it is a part of the ISC, and the ISC is the government's adviser. He used the Industrial Relations Commission analogy. He said that advocates—trade unionists and others—would emerge to represent these consumers, as happens in the Industrial Relations Commission, where advocacy is allowed. But is it not true that, unlike the Industrial Relations Commission, these people who emerge as advocates will not have the right to represent the vast majority of workers in the tribunal's dealings with them?

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —In relation to the first point, the officers of the tribunal are independent statutory appointments. They are independent of the ISC. There is no provision in the act for the ISC to direct those statutorily appointed officers.
—Sort of like the Foreign Investment Review Board.
—I do not know about the Foreign Investment Review Board. We are not discussing that tonight.
—No, but it is a model that the government likes.

—I realise what Senator Kernot is getting at, but we are not discussing that tonight. I will return to my comparison with the Industrial Relations Commission, which I am more familiar with. It will operate in that way.

PARA.TAB: Staff of the ISC will be staff of the tribunal. Frankly, I think that is an advantage, not a disadvantage. They will be paid by separate funding. It is not funded by the ISC. It is a separate organisation. I am confident that the tribunal will act in the best interests of complainants.
In relation to the second point, the tribunal has the power to allow advocates to appear before it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who will they be allowed to put in—anybody?

—Yes. We have to see how the practice of the tribunal will develop. Frankly, I think that is, again, a good thing. Let us assume that, as a matter of right, advocates appeared on behalf of the parties before the tribunal. PARA.TAB: The tribunal, in the initial stages particularly, will ensure that there is, in a sense, a balance of advocacy power before it. It is early days. This involves a very major change to the superannuation environment. It is not often that any government appoints a new independent semi-judicial body to handle an area of law. That is why the government has asked for time to see how the details of the caseload work out, and that is why it prefers the approaches that will be reflected in the motion to be moved by Senator Watson.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to put on the record that I want to see the tribunal work; that is very important. I want to see it gain the confidence and respect of all the parties involved in superannuation. I am just not convinced at the moment that it is giving consumers the best deal.
