DEBATE.TITLE: ABORIGINAL AND TORRES STRAIT ISLANDER COMMISSION AMENDMENT BILL (No. 3) 1993

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 19 November, on motion by Senator Sherry:
That this bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —On Friday, when we were last discussing the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1993, I made a point about the islands seeking self-determination. At that time, I was speaking about the Cook Islands, which the chairman of the Torres Strait Island Coordinating Council wishes to use as a role model. As I said, already the Cook Islands legislates on matters of income tax and immigration, and it is moving into areas of foreign affairs with the New Zealand government. It regularly updates its statements of international personality which allows it to join such international forums as the food and agriculture organisations of the UN and the South Pacific.

PARA.TAB: New Zealand really acts only on its request in matters of foreign affairs and defence. In the late 1980s, when New Zealand signed a medical agreement with Australia, the Cook Islanders were also invited to be part of that reciprocal arrangement, but they declined.

As a sign of its growing independence, the Cook Islands will be establishing a high commission in Canberra next year. While the Torres Strait Regional Council has said that it does not want to handle foreign affairs and defence, it wants the Australian government, itself and Papua New Guinea to negotiate a memorandum of understanding dealing with the implications of the Torres Strait treaty.
The other day in question time, Senator Robert Ray said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . given the boundary demarcation that has been agreed on, that would be a major factor for us to consider. There are all sorts of immigration and other matters that have to be taken into account . . .

It should also be noted that only sovereign nations can enter into treaties under international law. The Torres Strait Regional Council also wishes to administer the mainland communities of Bamaga and Seicia, which have a significant proportion of Aboriginal people, on the top of the Gulf.

PARA.TAB: While sympathising with the islanders who wish to do more for themselves, we must find a way that does not put at risk Australia's security and international arrangements. We must find a way that does not create more financial and economic burdens for a community which could not feasibly support itself for some time to come. We must find a way that ensures that the interests of other Queenslanders living on the Torres Strait who do not originally come from the islands—some 20 per cent, according to Senator Ray—also have their needs met.

As the islanders are claiming that the Mabo case strengthens their call for self-determination in the form of free association from Australia, the government must clarify whether, if a right to their land is not extinguished by the accession of British sovereignty, the right of self-government also survives. The point also should be made that even if the Torres Strait were to be constituted as a federal territory, this is no guarantee of greater political or economic autonomy to Torres Strait Islanders.

I have been to all the territories in my position as shadow minister for territories. Norfolk Island almost has self-government and autonomy. The Norfolk Island Act gives Norfolk Island a responsible legislative and executive government to enable it to run itself as much as possible. The federal government makes a contribution of only about $1.15 million a year. That is a totally different situation from that which applies to the Cocos Islands and Christmas Island, both of which have administrators. I believe that those administrators run those islands with very little input from the constituents of the islands. Having been to the Torres Strait a number of times, I think that it does have local self-government.

The bill we are debating now gives the Torres Strait Islanders their own important commission. It creates a separate Torres Strait regional authority—something the islanders have always wanted. I would say that they would possibly have as much as or even more autonomy than do the two territories of the Cocos Islands and Christmas Island.

The point should also be made that, even if Torres Strait Island were to be constituted as a federal territory, it has to be very careful that what it will get is more autonomy. Section 122 of the federal constitution allows for the Commonwealth to make laws for the government of any of its territories, which may or may not include self-government legislation. Bipartisan support is therefore necessary if this were to be the route to self-determination.

I cannot help but feel that the islanders have been led up the garden path by the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs (Mr Tickner), who cannot possibly have cabinet support to endorse self-government by the year 2001 in these terms. In the Queensland state parliament last Friday, Mr Goss, when asked about self-determination for the Torres Strait, said:

SPEECH.PARA: We have given no support or encouragement whatsoever for a self-government proposal. I believe it is fraught with difficulties.

I think it is absolutely irresponsible for Mr Tickner to tell the islanders that self-government by the year 2001 is an option when, in fact, it would have to have the support of the Queensland government to go through.

PARA.TAB: The minister, by not ruling out some of the demands, encouraged the islanders to believe they are feasible. To be master of one's own destiny is granted to a very few. Most of us do the best we can with what we have, and Australia has plenty. Any Queenslander who feels they want to have self-government and retain free association with Australia must carefully consider what they would be giving up in terms of social, economic and political aspects and ordinary security and support.

The issue of self-government in the Torres Strait raises a number of questions which I believe the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Senator Sherry) who is at the table should answer now. How far are the state and federal governments prepared to go with regard to self-determination? We have heard from Premier Goss and he has given it no encouragement. Therefore, I ask the parliamentary secretary to advise how far the federal government is prepared to go.

When will the government make the decision clear to the Torres Strait Islanders? What are the constitutional and legal implications of self-government with free association with Australia? What does the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Senator Gareth Evans) think about the islanders wanting to negotiate a memorandum of understanding with Papua Guinea over the Torres Strait treaty?

A number of matters should be made clear to the parliament of Australia and also to the Queensland parliament. But, most of all, they should be made clear to the Torres Strait Islanders who have been led to believe that self-government by 2001 is on the cards. If Mr Tickner has received the go-ahead from federal cabinet, this government is obliged to make that decision clear. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission Amendment Bill (No. 3) seeks to make a range of amendments to the ATSIC act. Many of the suggested changes arise as a result of the review of ATSIC carried out under the principal act to mark three years of ATSIC's work. I had some questions relating to the changes to general funding powers and to budget drafting processes which have partially been answered and which, no doubt, will be clarified by the minister during the committee stage.

PARA.TAB: In looking at the overall thrust of the bill, I could not help but wonder whether all the accountability changes will see ATSIC so bound up in accountability that it will not be able to deliver services on the ground. As these changes go so much to the heart of ATSIC, it seems odd to foster them. For this reason, the Greens will not be supporting the thrust of the opposition's foreshadowed amendments.

When concerns about ATSIC's accountability are raised—as, for example, in Senator Panizza's inquiry—it is relevant to put on the record the reasons why the Greens are not supporting these changes. I will summarise them because they also apply to the opposition's amendments.

TALK.START.PARA: —You will get another chance next year.

—I am sure that we will. I am sure that we will keep that option open. I will summarise the reasons why greater scrutiny and new processes being introduced to ATSIC are not favoured at this time by the Greens. Clearly, we are not saying that the agency is perfect. We can all point out areas in which money could be better spent or saved. In that regard, ATSIC is by no means unusual. There are some specific reasons why the Greens do not favour these changes. The chief amongst them is the forthcoming ATSIC elections which will be held in the next few weeks. We believe that an inquiry could dissuade some Aboriginal people from exercising their right to vote in the elections, thus making the regional councils less representative than they should be. As a number of criticisms of ATSIC seem to revolve around complaints of a lack of adequate representation by various communities and groups, such an effect would be counterproductive.

PARA.TAB: Secondly, I would be very concerned if the incoming councillors and commissioners were thrown straight into a major inquiry when they should be settling into doing the best job they can for the Aboriginal communities which elected them as their representatives. Also, the inquiry would absorb a great deal of the agency's resources at a time when they are needed in other areas.

The third reason that I have given for not supporting Senator Panizza's concerns has also, I believe, been addressed by ATSIC's own review of its first three years of operation. The results of that review are expressed in this legislation. An inquiry could duplicate a lot of the work that has already been done.

Finally, an inquiry is possibly premature, considering that ATSIC has not yet reached its fourth birthday. We agree that there is room for improvement but, because of the atmosphere that would be generated, we do not believe that either a parliamentary inquiry or the opposition's suggestion of increased accountability and procedures of greater scrutiny would be necessarily, for the reasons I have cited already, the best means of addressing the issues which have been raised.
We support the aspects of the bill relating to—

TALK.START.PARA: —What is the alternative—an open cheque?

—Senator Panizza asked what the alternative is. The alternative that we suggest is that the newly elected representatives of ATSIC be given a chance actually to put into action the kinds of procedures that are already established. They should be given the opportunity to truly represent their regional councils. Senator Panizza said he will be here next year. If there is a need for an inquiry or further accountability procedures, then that may well be an appropriate time to look at them. The Greens do not feel that now is that time.

PARA.TAB: We support the aspects of the bill relating to the establishment of the Torres Strait Regional Authority. The major concern of the Greens revolves around part 8, clause 18, on page 12 of the bill, in respect of the minister's involvement in making appointments relating to ATSIC. I foreshadow that we will be presenting amendments at a later stage. These amendments have the same effect as the government's proposal contained in the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission Amendment Bill (No. 1) 1993. As honourable senators will remember, the government's proposal was rejected by an amendment moved by the opposition and supported by the Australian Democrats.

At the time, I supported the government's proposal but was in no position to influence the decision. Since then I have received a strong lobby from Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people across Australia, including the ATSIC commissioners themselves. These people believe that it is only appropriate that if ATSIC is to be, and is to be seen to be, a vehicle for self-determination for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders, then all the commissioners who head this organisation should be elected.

It is in the interests of the government and of the parliament that ATSIC be fully empowered to set its own course in determining what is best for its constituency. Naturally, all the normal accountability functions will remain, and so they should when any government organisation is spending considerable amounts of public funds.

The amendments that I have circulated would come into operation from I January 1994, so they would not in any way affect the current round of ATSIC elections. In fact, the first time they would be used would be to elect the new commission in 1996-97. This is a full three years away—almost the same length of time as ATSIC has existed. During that period the organisation would have as much time to mature as it has since its inception.

We will present the amendments at the committee stage, unless two eventualities occur. Firstly, the government has expressed a concern regarding the starting date of the change. We want to put on the record that if the government circulates amendments that will ultimately succeed in achieving the same purpose as our amendments are designed to achieve, then I will be happy to withdraw them at that stage.

Secondly, I understand that the Democrats have some concern about the number of elected commissioners. They feel that, rather than there being 17 commissioners, the number should be raised to 19. I would like to assure them that if they wish to change the numbers, that essentially will have the support of the Greens as well. However, in this instance the particular proposition I am foreshadowing will be to make sure that election is the method by which the commissioners are chosen. This will add to the self-determination principles that the Greens support.

In conclusion, I wish to support the foreshadowed amendment by the Democrats regarding the preamble. I only wish that the rhetoric will be matched by the activities of this government and the activities of all the agencies that are attempting to support Aboriginal people on the ground.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1993 is the third and final part of the changes made to the ATSIC act. As we have heard, the impetus for these changes was the report to the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs (Mr Tickner) arising from the commission's review of its operations. How healthy it is that the commission should be prepared to review its operations at the end of its first term and how healthy it is that it should be willing to implement significant and meaningful changes as a result of that review.

PARA.TAB: The bill puts in place additional provisions for evaluation and audit procedures which will significantly improve accountabilities at all levels of the commission. The government's bill amends the ATSIC act to strengthen annual reporting provisions for regional councils, and guidelines are set down for the preparation of draft budgets which are to have reference to regional plans.

Overall, this bill puts in place a more simplified and efficient regime for the commission to apply when making grants or loans. These funding powers may be exercised only for the purpose of furthering the social, cultural or economic development of Aboriginal persons or Torres Strait Islanders.

The bill marks the beginning of a new phase for ATSIC and an opportunity to cement the vision of reconciliation and indigenous self-determination which the commission embodies. I believe strongly that the establishment of ATSIC has been one of the most important developments in Aboriginal affairs in recent times. It is clear that Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples are determining their own future.

ATSIC, through its system of elected regional councils and policy making board of commissioners, provides a means of empowerment and self-determination. While white Australia is grappling with the processes and consequences of owning its real history, indigenous people are claiming their future.

I think it is wonderful to note that there is a record number of nominations for the regional council elections of ATSIC to be held on 4 December. A total of 2,001 candidates have nominated for the 573 positions. This is an increase of 400 since the last and first election. Numbered among the candidates, interestingly enough, are many who have previously been very unsupportive of ATSIC. ATSIC has obviously proven its worth as a representative structure for Aboriginal peoples. These people now want to be part of the action. Three years ago, many people, including many from Aboriginal communities, doubted that ATSIC would survive. But now they realise that ATSIC has established itself as a forceful and independent political voice with real economic power.

Since 1990—and I remind honourable senators that ATSIC has been in existence for only three years; one term—ATSIC has been streamlined, with a reduction from 60 to 35 regional councils. This bill will put in place the final stage of that streamlining process and it dictates the new roles and responsibilities the elected councillors will have.

The government has put forward amendments which will allow the commission to remove regional councillors from office in certain situations. This will ensure that any failure to comply with those duties and responsibilities laid down in the act will be dealt with swiftly. It will mean that a high standard of administrative excellence is expected and will be maintained.

The Australian Electoral Commission has noted that the much greater interest in this round of ATSIC elections has had one beneficial side effect—that is, it has increased the number of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people on the electoral roll. It is estimated that an additional 6,000 indigenous Australians have enrolled to vote. I think it is also pleasing to note that of the 2,001 nominations for the elections, 700 are women. This represents an increase of 35 per cent over the 1990 figure.

Regional and national Aboriginal politics are unlikely to be fully representative of Aboriginal aspirations until they are able to reflect the extent of female influence within the Aboriginal population. Despite the outstanding accomplishments of ATSIC's current chairperson, Lois O'Donoghue, media attention to high profile Aboriginal spokespersons might suggest the dominance of males in Aboriginal politics. But it is the women in many Aboriginal communities who become active at the grassroots level to address concerns about housing for their families, the health and education of their children and employment opportunities.

As is the case with most political structures, the broader collective objectives of higher levels of Aboriginal political activity—whether national, state or even regional—are often seen as being too distant from the day-to-day struggles of people concerned with immediate needs and the allocation of those resources which might be available to satisfy these needs. ATSIC's emphasis on regional representation stands a real chance of overcoming this problem, perhaps more so than our state and federal parliaments. It is in this regional representation that we can increasingly see the position of Aboriginal women reflected in local communities.

The bill also provides for the establishment of the Torres Strait Regional Authority, which will supersede the Torres Strait Regional Council and will have powers and functions similar to the commission. I believe these changes will provide more effective representation in policy development and more efficient service delivery for Torres Strait Islander peoples within their region. I assure Senator Boswell that I have noted the arguments he put this evening and I will consider them.

The principle is that indigenous organisations and representatives should be able to shape policy for their people and not simply manage government programs. They should be able to run cooperative enterprises and administer local government functions for communities which happen to be indigenous. That is what self-determination has come to mean. But it is a political term with no guaranteed legal content. The concept of self-determination must be considered broadly. Indeed, subject to the constitution and laws of the Commonwealth, self-determination ought now to be seen as a non-controversial statement of the legitimate and recognisable aspirations of Aborigines seeking maximum community independence while remaining part of the nation state.

To this end, it seems appropriate that the enabling act of the commission should include a preamble which outlines the raison d'etre for the commission and provides a framework for its mission. The original ATSIC bill had one. I revisited the history and I know that the Democrats had a role in having that preamble removed. I want to rectify that this evening. That is why I wish to add a further amendment to the government's bill to include such a preamble. The addition of this preamble is not intended to change the overall operation of the act. The preamble I propose takes into account the High Court's decision on native title and acknowledges the indissoluble link between recognition of the rights of indigenous people and the process of reconciliation.

I congratulate ATSIC on its pivotal role in achieving positive outcomes in the negotiations on the native title bill. This role has demonstrated, as nothing else probably has, that Aboriginal politics have come of age. While there is still much to be achieved as ATSIC goes through an important and next transitionary stage towards becoming even more effective, it is important to acknowledge that it is moving forward all the time. The future of ATSIC, as a force in indigenous affairs, depends on strong community support through the regional councils structure.

I urge all indigenous people to vote in the elections; I am pretty sure we will have a fairly high turnout. Participation in these elections sends a clear signal that Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples are very much a part of this nation's political processes.

The bill also includes amendments relating to an independent review panel which will be set up to review the electoral systems put in place for the elections in December to enable permanent boundaries of regions, wards and zones to be determined before the following elections in 1996.

The Australian Democrats support this bill as a continuation of our longstanding commitment to ATSIC as the representative body for indigenous peoples. As I have said before, I think the attacks on ATSIC from indigenous and non-indigenous Australians are basically very unfair. ATSIC has had one term. It is unfair for us to expect a monolithic political view of indigenous people. We do not expect that of ourselves; we are here in our various political parties. I think it is unreasonable for us also to impose on ATSIC higher accountability than any other statutory authority.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why is that?
—Because it is discriminatory, basically.
—Senator Panizza says you don't know what you're talking about.
—That is okay; ATSIC and indigenous people know what I am talking about, and that is important to me. I really regret the attacks of people such as Ms Pat O'Shane and others.
—Because they go against your views.

—No. At a time when we need to acknowledge the good work that ATSIC has done in just three and a bit years of operation, I think we are being very unfair to expect of it unreasonably high outcomes in one term. What else do we expect? It has reviewed what has gone well and it has taken action where things have not gone well. Here we are, putting the last of the review's recommendations into place.

PARA.TAB: I look forward to the next elections; I think they will be incredibly interesting and dynamic. I look forward to congratulating the next ATSIC commissioners and meeting with them next February in Canberra. I will speak about my amendments at the committee stage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ferguson Sen A.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak briefly to the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1993 because of some concerns I have relating to replies received to questions raised in an estimates committee. Part 28 of the ATSIC bill relates to the establishment of the Torres Strait Regional Authority, which will replace the Torres Strait Regional Council. The coalition supports the setting up of the TSRA, particularly if its establishment leads to less duplication with ATSIC in the Torres Strait Islands.

PARA.TAB: However, I would like to bring to the attention of the Senate several concerns I have been pursuing through the Senate estimates process. I have asked a series of questions of the Department of the Environment, Sport and Territories relating to the implications of the High Court's Mabo decision for the Torres Strait and the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park.

Australia has set very high environmental standards relating to the protection of our waters and the marine, animal and plant life contained in those waters. These are standards that we should uphold at all costs and, where necessary, seek to improve and strengthen. Therefore, I am concerned to ensure that if a marine native title claim is successful in either of these areas, which I understand is a distinct possibility, the owners of that marine native title would continue to be bound by all the environmental protection laws and conditions which currently apply in these very sensitive waters.

I would like to say at the outset that I am definitely not implying that the owners of any marine native title in the Torres Strait or in the Great Barrier Reef area do not or will not share these objectives of upholding our environmental protection record. There is no doubt that people of Aboriginal and Islander descent care very much for our environment and have a great affinity with the land and our waters. However, I am concerned about equality before the law of all Australians.

In the light of the ambiguous and confusing answers that I have received through the estimates process, I am concerned that a different set of environmental protection laws could apply to holders of marine native title. If this were to occur, it would result in Australians—indigenous and non-indigenous—sharing the same waters and coastline being treated differently if a dispute about breach of our environmental protection law occurs.

At the first hearing of Estimates Committee E on September 21 I asked: if the Torres Strait Regional Authority is established, who will have the ultimate responsibility for environmental controls in the Torres Strait, particularly in the event of a claim for marine native title being accepted? The answer that I received via the Attorney-General's Department was:

SPEECH.PARA: The existence of any marine native title could have implications for the exercise by the Torres Strait Regional Authority of functions in relation to environmental and other matters. In particular, powers in relation to environmental matters would have to be exercised in a non-discriminatory manner. That is, any native title holders would have to be accorded the same rights and procedures as those accorded to any other interest holders in the area. Further, the proposed Torres Strait Regional Authority would also need to comply with any requirements in relation to dealings with native title areas that are contained in the Government's proposed legislative response to the High Court's Mabo decision.

Following the receipt of this answer, on 4 November I sought clarification as to this advice and asked which environmental powers of the Torres Strait Regional Authority the Attorney-General's Department was referring to. In an answer provided on notice by the Department of the Environment, Sport and Territories, I was advised that the functions of the authority, as set out in the bill, would not extend to controls currently in place with regard to the environment and fishing and would not entitle the authority to act inconsistently with the environmental legislation administered by the department. But while this is encouraging, on the very next page the clarification I sought from the Attorney-General's Department states:

If environmental functions were to be conferred on the Torres Strait Regional Authority then, irrespective of the source of any such powers and functions, their exercise by the authority in respect of any marine native title holders would have to be non-discriminatory for the purposes of the Racial Discrimination Act 1975. Once the proposed Commonwealth Native Title legislation commences operation, they will have to be exercised in accordance with it.

Whether a particular environmental law applied to any marine native titleholders would depend on the terms of the particular legislation. If in its terms it did apply, then to be valid it would need to satisfy the conditions referred to in the previous paragraph. Assuming that it did, then any native marine titleholders would have to comply with the law.

PARA.TAB: On the face of it, I think that this answer from the Attorney-General's Department raises more questions than it answers. While I understand the issue of traditional hunting and fishing and other similar issues where indigenous Australians are allowed to continue, within limits, traditional hunting of endangered species—like dugongs, for example—I am concerned that this answer from the Attorney-General's Department implies that other laws, like those relating to pollution controls, might not apply if somehow they were seen to be discriminatory against indigenous Australians under the Racial Discrimination Act.

I have no intention of scaremongering on this issue; I am just highlighting the response that was given to me by the Attorney-General's Department. I will be seeking further information and advice in the coming months. I certainly would have liked more time to be able to examine this advice from the Attorney-General's Department. The answer was delivered to my office only some time on Friday so I have not had time to examine it any further. However, I will be pursuing this issue along with other information that I have received through the estimates process relating to marine native title, environmental controls in the Torres Strait and the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park and the discussion regarding self-government in the Torres Strait. I believe that these issues are of concern to all Australians. I simply wish to place on record my interest in this area.

TALK.START.PARA: —My name was not on the speakers' list.
—No, it wasn't.

—That is all right; I have a right to speak on whatever bill I want to. My name was not on the list, but seeing that Senator Chamarette had something to say about my inquiry and that the minister had his own jibes along the way I just thought I would put a few facts straight.
—It would be a world first.

—The minister has been known to take his time, too. Anyone could be excused this evening, listening to Senator Chamarette, for thinking that her delivery in this debate was to do with my proposed inquiry. She had her chance at the time—and I do not know whether she picked it up or not—to talk on my motion. But I know that since she and the Democrats helped defeat my motion their offices have been hounded by people asking them for reasons why they did not support it. I know that. So Senator Chamarette took it upon herself tonight to get up and explain things to those people who may have been listening, or she may put it in writing and send it off. Maybe that is why she did not support my motion.

PARA.TAB: I said at the time that my inquiry was about accountability and nothing else. I never questioned the amount of money going into ATSIC. I said it was entirely a matter of accountability, and accountability alone. Senator Chamarette and Senator Kernot used the excuse that there was another inquiry going on in another place, namely the ATSIC standing committee in the House of Representatives, which was charged with looking at the Auditor-General's report. That was why I decided to move for an inquiry—going on the Auditor-General's report and the demand I have had from a lot of Aboriginal communities around Australia.

Senator Chamarette knows who they are because they have got on to her—the Gubrun in Kalgoorlie, the Ozies clan in Broome and various communities in Perth. They have been on to Senator Chamarette's and Senator Kernot's offices as well as mine looking for an inquiry. That is why I proposed the idea of an inquiry and they decided to go agin it. I was happy to accept the decision at the time and said that it was only the end of the beginning. Senator Kernot used the excuse that there was an ATSIC election coming. I offered to Senator Kernot to put it off until next year. She did not accept that. I was prepared to put it off to next year, but no, Senator Kernot did not take that one up. She used this inquiry.

As I said in an interjection, she will have another chance next year. I have put forward that if that committee has not properly addressed the matter by next year then she will have another chance to do exactly what I was trying to do this year. I think it was Senator Kernot who mentioned that we want to put on ATSIC a higher degree of accountability than we put on someone else, but she did not put forward any argument as to why she believed that. I have never proposed putting a higher degree of accountability on anyone than I am prepared to accept myself. As I have said before, Senator Kernot and Senator Chamarette will have their chance next year, but they should not accuse me—or my colleagues, for that matter—of trying to impose a higher degree of accountability on ATSIC than we impose on anyone else.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission Bill that is currently before us. I do so because this evening on the channel 7 news there was a very important feature news item in the section called `Money Matters' that related to the implications that could flow from the native title Mabo legislation and also the current situation with regard to the various audits that are being very properly conducted into the operation of the Northern Land Council and the Aboriginal Benefits Trust Account in the Northern Territory. In the context of that interview this evening, the director of the Northern Land Council, Mr Darryl Pearce, made a number of comments that very specifically addressed the issues of audit.

PARA.TAB: I was also interviewed in that particular program. I alluded to the fact that it had been necessary very recently, arising from the considerations of the Senate estimates committees during this year, to refer a very important audit reference to the Auditor-General with regard to a number of very unsatisfactory financial arrangements of both the Northern Land Council and the Aboriginal Benefits Trust Account.

During this year, Walter and Turnbull, consultants to ATSIC, have now made two very significant audit reports to ATSIC on the implications of the Aboriginal Benefits Trust Account which concern me greatly because they affect many constituents in the Northern Territory. I am sure that Senator Collins would share my concerns about the operation of the Aboriginal Benefits Trust Account in the last few years, particularly the issues that have been addressed in that fundamental report of Walter and Turnbull where millions of dollars that is directly the property of Aboriginal people have gone in funny ways and not been properly accounted for.

The Aboriginal Benefits Trust Account, whilst it flows through consolidated revenue, is really the accumulation of mining royalties that are very properly the private ownership of the Aboriginal traditional owners. Because a certain proportion of those funds flows to the land councils in the Northern Territory for their administration, it is concerning when the auditors then identify that, because of either lousy administration or perhaps more serious considerations, millions of dollars of funds are, in effect, siphoned off and are not then available to the traditional owners directly or for the operation of Aboriginal communities specifically in the Northern Territory.

I had early discussions with the Australian National Audit Office as it was setting in place the preliminary audit and I know the range of issues it will be addressing. I am very hopeful that the Auditor-General's report will be tabled in this parliament before we rise in December. As I said earlier, that report is fundamental because it goes to the core of millions of dollars that are not flowing properly for the individual benefits of Aboriginal traditional owners and Aboriginal communities for grants.

In addressing this legislation specifically, I look particularly at page 5 dealing with amendments relating to the functions of the Office of Evaluation and Audit. I am well aware that my colleague Senator Troeth will be moving a number of amendments to beef up this area so that the specific areas of audit should embrace those that relate to a regional council. This is most important. I would like to have seen the whole section go much further, particularly with regard to the audits of the land councils that operate in the Northern Territory under the provisions of the Aboriginal land rights act and also to the Aboriginal Benefits Trust Account itself. Unfortunately, at this stage it was not appropriate to move that as an amendment.

I would certainly urge Mr Pearce, the Director of the Northern Land Council, and Mr David Ross, the Director of the Central Land Council, to very carefully take note of the functions that have now been added to the Office of Evaluation and Audit under ATSIC, to be very mindful of those powers and, in response to the Auditor-General's report that will be tabled here this year, to consider further legislation that may be necessary. As I said in my opening remarks, I was concerned at the exclusive and proprietary interests that Mr Darryl Pearce attempted to take tonight in the debate. I do not think there is any need for any Aboriginal leader or person to get precious on this particular issue particularly where issues have been identified, through the process of audit, as being of very major concern.

I believe we do have to wait for that report of the Auditor-General in the next few weeks. I anticipate that it will raise very significant principled issues. On behalf of those Aboriginal people living in the Northern Territory, I hope that this will be an ongoing process in the further reviews that will be necessary to the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission Amendment Bill.

I join with Senator Kernot in expressing my joy at the number of candidates who have offered for election at the ATSIC regional council elections on 4 December. I think it is a very democratic and principled process that has now been set in place. I trust that the new councillors, and subsequent commissioners in the next ATSIC commission, will be very mindful of their audit and evaluation roles.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will address briefly a couple of substantive concerns that were raised by Senator Boswell and Senator Ferguson. Senator Boswell raised the question of the government's position on a potential form of self-government for the Torres Strait Islands. I can assure Senator Boswell that the government has not taken a policy position on what that might be. I would imagine that a great deal of discussion and consultation with the communities in the Torres Strait will have to occur before the government moves to a position on that.

PARA.TAB: I am pleased to note Senator Boswell's support, as indeed the support of Senator Ferguson, for the establishment of the authority because I believe that it will lead a greater efficiency in terms of the operations of the responsibilities in that region and will be far more warmly embraced by the people of the Torres Strait as a result. But it should not be confused—and I am sure Senator Boswell is not confusing it—with any proposition to provide a form of self-government for the Torres Strait Islands. The government does not have a position on that at this time.

In respect of the very important question that Senator Ferguson raised of conservation laws, I did not note anything inconsistent in the advice that Senator Ferguson read out. In fact, that advice confirms my own understanding of the primacy of these laws. The reference, of course, to not being applied in a discriminatory way in respect of the Racial Discrimination Act is correct; that is, that conservation laws which apply to all people in Australia will apply to Aboriginal people in a non-discriminatory way. So the RDA does not have any impact on that. I can assure Senator Ferguson that native title rights to hunt, gather and fish will be subject to normal conservation restrictions. I have provided, if not the Senate then a committee of the Senate, with that advice previously. That is the case.

TALK.START.PARA: —What if it cuts across the Racial Discrimination Act?

—The Racial Discrimination Act does not have any particular application to conservation laws. The RDA simply says that one cannot discriminate against a group of people in a way which is racially based. Providing that the conservation laws apply to everyone else in Australia in that same way, they will apply to Aboriginal people. That will not be a breach of the RDA if that is the case. If a conservation restriction applies to Aboriginal people, providing that that restriction applies in precisely the same way to any other group of people in the Australian community, it will not offend the RDA.
—So I can hunt, gather and fish?

—No, Senator Crichton-Browne could not because, with respect, he is turning the Racial Discrimination Act on its head. As I have said before, native title rights to hunt, gather and fish will be subject to normal conservation restrictions. One will find contained within those restrictions the provision for Aboriginal people to hunt, gather and so on. I might add that those rights do not involve the right to hunt, gather or forage to the extinction of the particular wildlife that we are talking about.

PARA.TAB: Normal conservation rules will apply and, providing they are applied equally to Aboriginal people, they will not offend the RDA. I might add that, for example, things like statutory fishing rights, if they are contained in statute, will prevail over the rights of native titleholders.

What the High Court has made clear in one of its decisions—a decision which I think has been, in some cases, capriciously and, in others, maliciously misinterpreted by people who have attempted to interpret it—is that, in the case of freehold title and leasehold title, those statutory rights which people possess in Australia extinguish native title and any statutory rights, for example, to fishing stocks, will prevail over native title rights.

TALK.START.PARA: —With leases they will suspend it.

—Senator Crichton-Browne is correct. What I am saying is that we have to examine the rights involved. To give another example, if those existing rights already contain reservations in favour of Aboriginal people, as do the pastoral laws of the Northern Territory, Western Australia and South Australia, those rights are preserved.

PARA.TAB: The one thing I would say in conclusion on that point, though—and I do not think a lot of people realise this yet—is that there will be a raft of consequential legislation required to be passed by the states and territories following the passage, which I hope will be speedy, of the Native Title Bill through the parliament. There are a number of laws that will be immediately and obviously affected, a classic example being the Land Rights Act in the Northern Territory. Others include the deeds of grant and trust legislation in Queensland; the Pitjantjatjara lands legislation in South Australia; the sacred sites legislation, and so on. Legislation will need to be examined by all states and territories—and the Commonwealth will certainly be encouraging them to do so; not that I think they need any encouragement—and the Commonwealth also, over the next one or two years, will be examining all of its own legislation to ensure that that legislation also is brought into accordance with the provisions of the native title act.

We heard a cry of concern in the Senate the other day that the federal government's Native Title Bill is complex. There is no way that it can be anything else. There is no simple approach to the decision of the High Court of Australia. It is worth stressing—

TALK.START.PARA: —The telecommunications law was complex; so was the corporations law.

—Senator Kernot is correct. Hers is a very valid point. Honourable senators might refer to a speech to which I referred in earlier debates on Mabo before we even saw a gleam in the eye of the legislation, a speech which was made in the other place by the honourable member for Melbourne Ports (Mr Holding), a former Minister for Aboriginal Affairs and former distinguished barrister at the Melbourne bar. Mr Holding quite rightly pointed to the raft of legal cases and generations of lawyers enriched by the provisions relating to interstate trade in the Australian constitution. Of course, all of those provisions became synonymous with the name of Sir Garfield Barwick in tariff cases and tax cases.

PARA.TAB: The law is incredibly complex and decisions of the High Court can often have far reaching implications. I think it is extraordinary that, somehow or other, this landmark decision of the High Court—and there is no question that it is a land mark decision—is not somehow more uniquely troublesome, more uniquely equipped to give problems for lawyers than the mass of provisions of the—

TALK.START.PARA: —What about Mr Court's legislation; it is simple.
—I do not think I should divert too far from this ATSIC debate which, of course, has nothing whatever to do with native title.
—You're the one who started this debate.
—I beg your pardon, I am the one who started the ATSIC debate?
—No, this one here.
—The bill actually provides for the ATSIC debate.
—No, you're the one who started the Mabo debate.
—With great respect—

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator McKiernan)—Order! Senator Panizza.

TALK.START.PARA: —With great respect to Senator Panizza, I am responding directly to concerns that were raised by his colleagues—and they are nodding in assent. The Mabo question has been raised and I am responding to it. In respect of Senator Panizza's interjection about how simple Mr Court's legislation is, it is nothing of the sort.
—Lawyers won't grow fat on that one.

—With respect, I differ; perhaps if the lawyers do not grow fat on it, Aboriginal people will not either because it provides them with absolutely no rights at all. The thing that is most offensive and obnoxious about the Western Australian Mabo legislation is that clause 7 of that bill purports to extinguish all native title rights in a blanket extinguishment and replace them with a so-called right for occupational uses by Aboriginal people. The bill then goes on to make it transparently clear that that right provides no possessory rights for Aboriginal people at all—no proprietary rights at all. It then goes further.
—It has been amended since then.

—I am delighted to hear that. The original bill, which I have read—I have not caught up with the amendments yet—then goes further to make it clear that that right, so-called, is subservient to any other interest in the land. Then, to top it off, just in case people think that is giving Aboriginal people too much of a fair go, at the end of that division, it gives the minister the right to even extinguish completely those rights of Aboriginal people in accordance with `for any purpose' under any law of Western Australia simply by the publication of a notice. With the greatest respect to Senator Panizza, what the Mabo legislation in Western Australia says is that Aboriginal people have the right to walk around the place until somebody says they should not, and then they cannot. It is obnoxious indeed and does not, I am afraid, provide the simplicity that Senator Panizza thinks it does. In my view, it will be successfully struck down by challenge to the High Court, which means it does not give anybody the certainty that they are looking for—which the Commonwealth bill does.

PARA.TAB: But, to return again to the substantive question raised by Senator Ferguson—and it is an important question—the Commonwealth will be reviewing all of its legislation and the states and territories will have to review all of theirs over the next one or two years to ensure that those acts are, so far as possible, consistent with the Racial Discrimination Act.

I concur with the views expressed by Senator Kernot and probably also by Senator Chamarette, although I regret that I did not hear what Senator Chamarette had to say. I congratulate ATSIC on what I think has been an impressive record in its first term of office in administering the portfolio that it administers on behalf of Aboriginal people of Australia. I think it has done it exceedingly well. I believe, along with other senators in this chamber, that the passage of this last package of amendments to the ATSIC legislation will help it to do that a lot better. I know that there will be more intense interest in the ATSIC elections this time around than ever before, as other senators have mentioned. That is something we should all welcome.

In conclusion, I can indicate that it is the intention of the government not to support the amendment moved by Senator Chamarette—not because we disagree with any of its principle; on the contrary, we agree with it. But I think the amendment which has been moved by Senator Kernot has picked up some of the drafting difficulties we discovered in Senator Chamarette's amendment earlier today, and I am sure that Senator Chamarette will be quite relaxed about having her amendment not supported in favour of Senator Kernot's amendment.

I also indicate that the Opposition's amendment will be opposed, and I will save those remarks for the committee stage. I was horrified to hear Senator Tambling say that he would have liked to have seen the opposition's amendment go further because the effect of it, as I think I will be able to demonstrate to the chamber, is utterly unworkable.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
Clause 1.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Collins) made the statement a few minutes ago that the government had not taken a position of self-government for the Torres Strait Islands. I refer him to an article in which the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs, Mr Tickner, was quoted as saying, `Self-government by 2001 was highly likely . . . provided Torres Strait residents established a uniform goal'.

PARA.TAB: I see some conflict between Mr Tickner's statement and Senator Collins's statement. They seem to be utterly opposed to each other. Mr Tickner is saying that self-government is highly likely by 2001 and Senator Collins is saying that the government has not taken a position. Can the minister say whether he or Mr Tickner is wrong?

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not think there is anything wrong with my understanding of the English language. I think the words that Senator Boswell has just read out have confirmed that there is no conflict between what the minister said and what I said. The minister was expressing his view, his hope—his prayer, no doubt—that that will be the case. For a minister to say that he thinks it is highly likely is not a statement of government policy.

PARA.TAB: I reiterate that any question as important and substantial as a form of self-government for the Torres Strait Islands is a matter that at the end of the day will be considered by cabinet, and the government will take a position on it. It has not been considered by cabinet. To the best of my knowledge there is no immediate plan to have it considered by cabinet. Therefore, the government does not have a position on it.

The Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs, Mr Tickner, is perfectly at liberty to make statements about his own aspirations, suggestions and prognostications. I guess we all do from time to time on things like the republic and we attach that to the year 2000 as well. It seems to be a handy year to attach all sorts of things to. The only thing I know for certain about the year 2000 is that I will be considerably older than I am now, if alive. I am not certain on anything else about it. I reiterate that there is no conflict between the two statements. The matter has not been considered by government. At this point in time, the government does not have a position on it.

TALK.START.PARA: —I mentioned in my speech on the second reading that the government had informed me that it would be moving some amendments that covered the purpose of the amendments that have been circulated in my name, with the exception of a change of date from January 1994 to July 1996. I was not informed until after my speech that the government would move its amendments via the Australian Democrats. I am equally happy to withdraw my amendments in favour of those put forward by Senator Kernot.

PARA.TAB: The Greens support these because they address the most important issue of self-determination via election rather than appointment of the position of commission chairperson and remove any paternalistic overtones of the 19 May debate in which the principle of appointment was retained. I mention this now because I am not able to participate further and I did not want the committee to be left in doubt of my position. We will be supporting the Democrats' amendments but opposing those of the opposition.

TALK.START.PARA: —Very briefly, I would like to thank Senator Chamarette for her indication of not proceeding with her amendments. But I will just explain very briefly that the government amendments would not be moved by the Australian Democrats. We would move them. Having examined the proposed amendments that were shown to me earlier today and since the Greens' advice to the government, we were intending to move amendments. But, having seen the proposed amendments by the Democrats, which address the same concerns as the government amendments, I decided that we would not proceed with the government amendments and defer to the amendments that Senator Kernot is about to move, which have the same effect.
—Are the amendments identical? That is my only concern. If they cover the same principles that we discussed, I am happy to withdraw my amendment, as I said before.
—They do.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —What are the constitutional and legal implications of self-government with free association with Australia? Would the minister be able to give me some help on that? Does it have to be done by a referendum?

—I think Senator Boswell would be far better directing his inquiry to a constitutional lawyer rather than to an untutored, uneducated oaf like me. I will ensure that Senator Boswell's remarks are addressed.

PARA.TAB: In general terms, the question is, with respect, premature by a long way. There are a host of constitutional and legislative procedures that would need to be examined. Primarily, there would obviously need to be a significant amount of discussion and consultation with the people of the Torres Strait Islands before the government even came close to clarifying what its position may or may not be at the end of the day in respect of those issues.

For example, whether the matter needed to be addressed by referendum would depend on whether the decision taken by the government at the end of the day had any constitutional implications. At this point there is no reason to presume that that would be the case. In fact, my own view—for what it is worth, and it is worth as much as Mr Tickner's at the moment, considering that the matter has not come to cabinet—would be that the government would be very loath to propose any solution that would require constitutional amendment. I will tell the Senate what grounds I have for saying that, I think, with some authority.

When the Christmas and Cocos Islands elected to become part of the Australian community, constitutional considerations prevented those territories being incorporated into the state of Western Australia. I do not remember the detail of the constitutional advice but I certainly saw it at the time. It was a matter of constitutional convenience that the territories had to be incorporated for electoral purposes into the territories of either the ACT or the Northern Territory. I see that Senator Tambling, who I know recalls this—he was active in public life at the time—is nodding in agreement.

That is the reason. Not surprisingly, the Commonwealth was loath at that stage to contemplate something as horrendously complex and, I might add, expensive as constitutional change to incorporate the territories. That is why they are constitutionally, in legislative terms, part of Senator Tambling's electorate and my own. They are the reasons that I think it would be highly unlikely that a solution—

TALK.START.PARA: —You would have to consult with Queensland and Papua New Guinea as well before it got in place.

—Senator Tambling is correct—for that reason, I think it is highly unlikely that such a proposal would be considered. All I am saying, in conclusion, is that it is very premature to even be discussing those sorts of theoretical possibilities because I think it is a long way off yet.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senators Collins cannot blame me for bringing this issue forward when his colleague the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs (Mr Tickner), possibly with a rush of blood to the head when he got up there on those beautiful islands, told the Islanders that self-government was a prospect by the year 2001. I would like Senator Collins to point out to Mr Tickner that this has raised expectations amongst the Islanders, who have had this vision of self-government by the year 2001 for as long as I have been going up there.

PARA.TAB: These people have had their expectations raised, only to have them dashed by Senator Collins tonight and also by the Premier of Queensland when he said, `We have given no support or encouragement whatsoever for the self-government proposal. I believe it is fraught with difficulties'. I just want to point out to Senator Collins, as someone in this parliament who is acknowledged as an expert on Aboriginals, that he should take a strong message to Mr Tickner not to put his foot in his mouth before he engages his brain.

TALK.START.PARA: —I make it absolutely clear that I have not dashed anybody's hopes and nor have I raised them. I am simply indicating that there is nothing inconsistent in what I have said, and that is that the government has not adopted a position on self-government—whatever that might be, because the very words need a lot more definition than they currently have in terms of what that might require. There is nothing inconsistent in what I have said about it and what Mr Tickner has said about it.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have three amendments. I will put them separately but speak to them together for convenience. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1)Clause 2, page 2, at end of clause add the following subclause:

PARA.TAB: "(4) Part 30A and Schedule 4 commence on 1 July 1996.".

SPEECH.PARA: The amendments allow for the election of the chairperson of ATSIC. In doing so, we have to reduce the number. The existing subsection (1) says, `A chairperson and 18 other'. The effect of this amendment is to substitute the number `17'.

PARA.TAB: The first amendment is that this second part will take effect from 1 July 1996. Senator Chamarette's original amendment took effect from the beginning of 1994. This would have affected the coming December elections because the last stage of those elections, which is the election of the zone commissioners, would not have happened until February 1994. It was not intended by Senator Chamarette, I think, that this should take effect until the next round of elections in 1996. So the first amendment deals with the starting date and, basically, the second amendment and consequent amendments to the schedule are consequential upon the definitions of `elected commissioner' and `non-elected commissioner'.

It was my intention to move this package of amendments in February next year. I would like to have had the opportunity to have spoken with the new board of commissioners. I would particularly like to ask members of the board how to deal with the problem of the reduction of numbers because I know, in consultation with ATSIC, that we have not found an easy solution to the situation in which when the chairperson is elected the zone from which he or she comes will not have its zone commissioner. Therefore, it is desirable to have a by-election or a casual vacancy so that the chairperson can be an ambassador at large for ATSIC and then the zone from which the chairperson comes will still be represented by another commissioner. We could not arrive at an agreed upon position whereby, if the chairperson were to retire halfway through his or her term, the person filling the casual vacancy may come from a zone different from the next elected commissioner. That is something that I want to take up with the new board of commissioners when it meets next February. I am moving this amendment now, in November, when I was intending to move it in February next year.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are just ahead of you again.

—Not just Senator McMullan. It was not that. I was preferring to wait until the new board of commissioners was in place, but doing it now will not take that opportunity away from me. That is why I am signalling that there are still issues that I wish to take up with the new board so that we can work out the best and fairest way to deal with this reduction in numbers.

"(g)to report on evaluations and audits conducted in accordance with sub-paragraph (c)(iii), (c)(iv), (c)(v), (c)(vi), (c)(vii) or (c)(viii), in writing, to the Commission and the Minister at least every 3 months.".

Both of these amendments relate to accountability. In view of some of the remarks expressed tonight about accountability, I suggest that these amendments are not unreasonably high. Accountability is about the use of taxpayers' money.

PARA.TAB: Through the first amendment, we propose to move regional councils into the group of bodies that are to be audited regularly. A regional council will be joined with the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission, Aboriginal Hostels Ltd and the Commercial Development Corporation so that a regional council, as well as those bodies, will be evaluated and audited regularly.

The coalition sees no reason why regional councils should not be audited also as a requirement. If public money is being used, it should be subject to scrutiny—and I wish to echo the remarks of my fellow senators, Senator Ferguson and Senator Panizza—on the grounds of accountability. All public bodies should be regularly scrutinised and we fail to see why regional councils should not be subject to this also.

The second part of the amendment deals with the fact that under the legislation the evaluation or audit is to be at the discretion of the minister and as required by the organisation concerned. The coalition would prefer to see this requirement on a regular basis. We realise that there are quite a few bodies or organisations which would be involved in this evaluation or audit, but we suggest that the amount of work will vary according to the size of the organisation or the size of the body involved and that it will be lesser or greater according to that size.

The explanatory memorandum deals with strengthening the role of the Office of Evaluation and Audit. We suggest that, unlike the draconian effects suggested by some of the other speakers, our amendment does want to strengthen it further and that, by these amendments being implemented, that result would be effected.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I said during the second reading debate, the government is as concerned as the opposition about accountability for ATSIC to the point where I think more scrupulous accountability provisions have been provided for ATSIC than have been provided for many other organisations. The difficulty we have with the proposal of Senator Troeth is not so much its accountability ramifications but its unworkability. Frankly, I did not think the opposition would press this amendment because of the horrendous implications that it involves in terms of administrative unworkability and, I might add, sheer cost. It is just out of all proportion to the alleged benefit that would be received.

PARA.TAB: Clause 1 of the amendment deals with regional councils. I make the obvious point that regional councils are not actually in receipt of grants from ATSIC. They consider how those grants are to be spent, but apart from their own relatively small operating budgets, the regional councils themselves are not recipients of these grants. They are simply conduits for the grants to be sent out to the recipients and clause 2 of the amendment covers all of those people.

The government proposals currently before the Senate allow the minister—a power he does not currently have—or the commission to request the Office of Evaluation and Audit to evaluate or audit the activities of grant and/or loan recipients. That already exists in what the government is putting to the Senate. What the opposition's amendment does is make those audits from the Office of Evaluation and Audit mandatory. I see Senator Troeth nodding in agreement.

There is a difficulty with that. ATSIC currently provides around 6,000 grants or loans a year to approximately 1,500 organisations, all of which are subject to financial scrutiny. In fact, the grants cannot be provided unless the organisations are subject to financial scrutiny. Every Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander organisation is required by its incorporating legislation to have its books of accounts audited every year. Those organisations are required to provide a copy of their audited financial statements to the commission as a condition of the grant. Unless they provide proper audited accounts, they do not get the money. Organisations which do not comply with the requirement cannot receive any funding until they comply.

Those Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander organisations incorporated under the Aboriginal Councils and Associations Act, which are still the vast majority, are also required to lodge a copy of their audited annual financial statements to the Registrar of Aboriginal Corporations. The registrar has powers to investigate irregularities in their activities. The registrar may also take action to deregister an organisation which does not supply audited annual financial statements.

The Office of Evaluation and Audit, which Senator Troeth wants to visit with this responsibility, currently has a staff of about 20 people, and utilises external consultants. With that staff of 20, and utilising external consultants, during 1992-93 the office was able to conduct about 40 audits and complete eight evaluations of ATSIC programs and offices. I might add that this is an additional audit. The organisations themselves, I stress again, have to provide proper audited statements or they do not receive the grants in the first place. But the Office of Evaluation and Audit, with 20 staff and external consultants, did carry out 40 audits and eight evaluations of ATSIC programs and offices.

If the office was required, as this amendment will ensure that it will be, to conduct an additional 1,500 audits a year, whether they were needed or not, it would require in the order of an additional 200 staff to be employed, plus infrastructure, costing in excess—I think this has been a conservative estimate—of $15 million. The proposed coalition amendment, therefore, is clearly impractical. It is unworkable and unnecessary. That is why I am surprised that it is even being pressed. The current government proposals allow the minister to call in that office and request an audit to be done where necessary, on top of all the arrangements that are currently in place, as I have said. It makes no sense to expend this enormous amount of additional money or employ these additional people on the requirement of mandatory additional audits by this office to what literally would be hundreds, if not a thousand, organisations.

The amendment currently before the Senate is already a major enhancement of the accountability of ATSIC funded organisations. The OEA cannot at present audit the activities of any Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander organisation and the government proposals ensure that that can be done when it is necessary. Concerns about individual organisations can be, and are, raised from time to time in the Senate, the House of Representatives and the committees of either house of parliament. If these concerns are raised with the minister and are given public scrutiny and the minister believes that to involve the office would assist in the clarification of these issues the minister can do that.

Senator Tambling has already mentioned tonight a number of occasions where the minister has involved this office. We are awaiting—I can assure Senator Tambling with as much interest from me as from him—the report of the councils which will be lodged, I hope, in a couple of weeks time. To require by rote, as this amendment does, those additional audits where they are not necessary would, as I say, require the expenditure of around $15 million of public money totally unnecessarily and the employment of a further 200 people.

Under the government's proposals, any organisation which accepts ATSIC funds will henceforth be obliged to agree that it may be subject to OEA audit if either the commission or the minister have cause for concern. I might add, in conclusion, that I think the way that has been carefully constructed, with the greatest respect to the desire of the opposition, which we share—that is, to ensure the most scrupulous accounting requirements—involves ATSIC in a significant degree of initial responsibility in that under the government's proposals for optional audit by this office, ATSIC has the power itself to ask for these audits to be carried out without the minister even requiring them to be carried out.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thought Senator Chamarette might have been present so as to have another chance to explain why we demand more accountability of ATSIC than any other organisation. I am not talking about the degree of accountability. I invite her to come into the chamber and do so.

He expresses the view:

SPEECH.PARA: Community concern about accountability is on the rise, expenditures on Aboriginal programs are large and, usually in public administration these days, rising. Outcomes are widely criticised by the media, by politicians, by Aboriginals and by taxpayers and other members of the public. At the same time significant moves are being made both within and without ATSIC for increased Aboriginal control of the agenda. There is a new group of very competent Aboriginal people who along with veterans like Charles Perkins, are determined to use government programs and funds to create a long term independent economic base for Aboriginal Australians. The Federal government of the day, through its establishment of ATSIC and annually increased funding allocation to it supports the self management of Aboriginal persons, in its rhetoric it acknowledges their right to self determination as well as recognition of their indigenous cultural heritage. It should be stressed that there is nothing new in this trend towards greater accountability. Over a long period in parliament a number of people, but particularly Senator Grant Tambling of the Northern Territory, have raised a series of allegations about maladministration in the old Department of Aboriginal Affairs and in Aboriginal Development Commission (ADC) during the 1980's. The Fraser Government having established the Aboriginal Development Commission in 1980 with a very significant reduction in the extent of ministerial control and oversight—
I am again quoting Mr Fred Chaney—

(for which I was responsible as minister at the time) the present government found defending the allegations difficult. With the proposal to establish the ADC and to substitute a much broader body with democratic Aboriginal control—
namely, ATSIC—

the then Minister, Gerry Hand, told the parliament "There is no other department or statutory authority in existence in the Commonwealth which will be as accountable as ATSIC". (8) and as Frank Brennan describes Hand went on to defy the opposition to find him "any organisation under this government or any other government which will be as accountable as this structure" (9)

Well, I think the challenge remains. Who on the opposition side can meet that challenge today? Where is there any organisation under this government or any other government which will be as accountable as ATSIC? The last part that I will quote is whether we:

. . . apply the same rigorous accountability standards to the States and to other Commonwealth Departments receiving money for Aboriginal advancement. States receive all manner of special funding to meet the needs of their disadvantaged Aboriginal citizens. Aboriginal citizens in any event are entitled to the same consideration as non Aboriginal citizens. Where is the web of accountability—
where is the opposition seeking this—
identifying failures in such provisions?—

to states and other Commonwealth departments? I think we are being unfair here. We expect ATSIC to comply, but we do not apply the same rigorous provisions to state government and departments receiving money for Aboriginal advancement.

TALK.START.PARA: —The committee is really talking about two things: accountability and policies. We are all concerned about the fact that, in many cases, taxpayers' money is not going to assist the people whom it is meant to assist—the Aboriginal people. It is not even hitting the mark. It is not being properly shared. In many respects, it is not being properly managed. All of the accountability in the world will not overcome that.

PARA.TAB: I have seen a number of projects where the money was impeccably accounted for but was a complete waste of taxpayers' money. I have been on the receiving end myself. Some years ago, I suppose 19 years ago—nobody in this chamber will remember it—I was accused of losing $55,000 of funding for training and education. I did not lose it; I invested it. I was not prepared to see that money expended because I knew that there was another program of trade union training. It was state government money. Muggins that I was, I saved it; I invested it for the state government in order to acquit it at the end of the year.

I was barrelled from pillar to post because I had done that. I could have spent it. I could have called for applications for a director of trade union training. TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 21 September 1993:

(5) Which of these orders have been subject to tender.

PARA.TAB: (1) AUSTRAC (Australian Transactions and Reports Analysis Centre) purchased 100 ties at $22.50 each on 10 February 1993 and 17 ties at $15 each on 16 February 1993.

(2) AUSTRAC is frequently visited by senior representatives of overseas government organisations. TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 7 October 1993:

PARA.TAB: (1) Why are young people from New Zealand who are studying in Australia being denied Medicare benefits as from 1 July 1993 when the reciprocal health agreement between New Zealand and Australia to bring this new regulation into effect has not yet been signed.
(2) Why are New Zealand students who do not require visas not being informed that they cannot obtain Medicare benefits.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) All overseas students in Australia, including students from New Zealand, are outside the Medicare arrangements. By Government decision, from 1 July 1993 all overseas students studying in Australia are required to contribute to Overseas Students Health Cover (OSHC). The reciprocal health care agreement with New Zealand does not require amendments to give effect to this decision. New Zealand students are being enrolled in OSHC.

(2) On 10 December 1992 the Deputy Prime Minister and the then Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services, Mr Howe, the then Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, Senator Button and the then Minister for Trade and Overseas Development, Mr Kerin announced in a joint press statement that from 1 July 1993 all overseas students will be insured under the OSHC arrangements. Pamphlets on the OSHC arrangements are available in Medibank offices.

There is a Memorandum of Understanding (MOU) between the Department of Health, Housing, Local Government and Community Services, Australian International Development Assistance Bureau, the Department of Employment, Education and Training and the Health Insurance Commission involved in the provision of OSHC. This MOU is currently being amended to clarify the status of New Zealand students as being eligible for OSHC.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services, upon notice, on 21 October 1993:

PARA.TAB: (1) Could details of any proposed lease arrangements where the Government has offered incentives, such as rental incentives, rent-free periods, cash incentives, or any other form of incentives or inducements to lease space over the past 12 months to other Government departments or private sector tenants in Government-owned property be provided.
(2) What are the details of the property description, the area in square metres and the quantum of the incentive package.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have been advised that the answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) The Department of Finance has issued guidelines on use of incentives in Government owned buildings in Estimates memoranda 1992/26 and 1993/2.

Government owned office accommodation, for which my Department is responsible, is managed on a commercial basis by Australian Estate Management. This includes the charging of market rents and, where appropriate, the offer of incentives. These incentives generally take the form of rents to reflect effective rents in the market place, rent free periods or assistance with tenant fitout costs.

The need for incentives varies according to the local market situation. In each case incentives, if offered, will be part of a total investment approach which meets the needs of the tenant as well as providing a commercial return on investment in the property. The form and extent of incentives is a matter between the particular tenant and the owner's representative, Australian Estate Management.

Other Commonwealth agencies with management responsibility for owned property, including statutory authorities, may offer incentives. Tenants of Government owned properties may also sub-lease space. The nature and extent of incentives involved in each case would be a matter between the parties concerned, in the accordance with the Department of Finance guidelines.
(2) As indicated information on incentives is treated as commercial-in-confidence.
